There are moments in "Selma" when I felt like I was watching Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. (played brilliantly by David Oyelowo) himself speaking on screen. Moments that made me want to clap my hands and stand up and cheer in approval of what he was saying. Moments when I was having to hold tears back. And these moments have stayed with me a couple of days after watching the film. These moments prove how timeless the story and issues are that "Selma" presents to us and although it would be difficult not to get these across, "Selma" does so in a way unlike any other biopic. David Oyelowo, a British actor, is fantastic and it is an absolute scandal that he has not been nominated for the Best Actor Oscar this year. Perhaps the Academy is still tapping themselves on the back for giving "12 Years a Slave" the Best Picture Oscar last year. When Oyelowo is making those speeches that King made to the Selma black clergy it was like I was watching King in the flesh. Oyelowo looks and sounds like King, effortlessly capturing his manner, grace and style and arguably most importantly his faith. Oyelowo simply pioneers the film in regards to performances, obviously helped along by the fame of his real-life counterpart, the other actors and actresses in the film simply revolve around him. This is especially obvious in the scenes where we get to see King and his colleagues deciding how to proceed in Selma. These backstage scenes seem just like how they would have been, providing an interesting viewpoint considering there isn't a lot of material detailing what happened. In these scenes King's colleagues also shine through, Colman Domingo (playing Ralph Abernathy) and Wendell Pierce (playing the Rev. Hosea Williams) are both worth mentioning for their performances. These scenes though do not focus on King and thus do well to emphasise that he was both not alone nor was a God of sorts, but just simply a great man, making him even more relatable and deserved of my sympathy.Of course "Selma" is a true story and the film sticks to it throughout ultimately doing it a perfect kind of justice. The fact that the film chose Selma as what it was going to cover was a good choice. There was the "battleground" that King decided to use as a means by which to end the struggle blacks had experienced in regards to registering to vote. It's ultimately the moments which have been well documented that are where the film thrives, "Bloody Sunday" for example. But where the film begins to waver is in its half-hearted commitment towards King's personal life and I believe this comes from how we obviously know less about King's personal life then what we know about him as leader of the Civil Rights Movement. It's those scenes where we see King giving speeches or leading the marches through Selma which are the film's best, whereas the hypothesised conversations between King and his wife, and meetings between the C.I.A. director J. Edgar Hoover and President Lyndon B. Johnson really bring the film out of focus."Selma" though is ultimately the best biopic I have ever seen. Although I've mentioned that King's personal life for me got in the way of the film, you have to see "Selma", not only because of how, as critic Richard Roeper put it, it's a film that provides a history lesson but certainly doesn't feel like a history lecture, but also because of how the film finally grants King the cinematic justice he deserves with a brilliant performance by Oyelowo.
A Powerhouse performance from everyone in the cast. Deserve to be the best picture.

Unpopular Opinion Alert: "Selma" is disappointing. Not because it's bad. Not even because it's not good. The fact is that is good. Well, it's fine ... it's alright. It's certainly not as good as it should be, as it deserves to be.It's refreshing for a biopic to be so focused on a particular chapter, rather than rushing through all the chapters of an historic figure's life. David Oyelowo is very good -- his omission from the list of Oscar nominations is simply wrong. He conveyed the entire spectrum of emotions, often with his face alone.However, "Selma" generates a surprisingly low emotional impact. It did not engage me the way it should have. There were moments -- too few and too obviously intended to shock the audience to attention -- but overall, i felt detached. The truth is that the first couple of times i saw the trailer on the big screen, i was moved -- literally shaking -- and there were tears. But the film fails to meet the expectations of the trailer ... and that is a shame.

"Selma" is full of powerful imagery that we'd like to pretend never happened but have a responsibility to pass on from generation to generation. This film tackles this dark chapter in American history with tact and honesty. While it has been met with criticism for its inaccurate portrayal of Lyndon B. Johnson, director Ava DuVernay sends a powerful message of equality through this story. The single factor that makes this a great film is the acting of David Oyelowo. His portrayal of Martin Luther King, Jr. is magic. The tone of his voice is a bit higher than King's but the cadence of his speaking is so accurate that you would think that it was King himself. It is hard to believe that this actor naturally has a British accent. It is unfortunate that Oyelowo was majorly snubbed by the Academy and I am positive that he would've earned an Oscar nomination (and probably won) in a less competitive year. His speeches after the death of Jimmie Lee Jackson and at the end are absolutely chilling. The other notable performance comes from Tom Wilkinson, portraying the tough position of the president when he's caught in the middle of a very public debate. There are several other big names in the film but the sheer number of characters allows many of them to only appear for a scene and then disappear. I find the film's nomination for Best Picture to be appropriate, but I also understand why it wasn't nominated in any other major categories. Its script doesn't stand out as being anything too special and the other aspects of the film recreate 1964 Alabama without being flashy, but the true magic of "Selma" is Oyelowo's on-screen manifestation of Martin Luther King, Jr. It is as if King walked out of the history books and onto the screen to once again share his powerful message of equality.

SELMA offers a new perspective on the legacy of MLK. It doesn't glorify him, but gives a deeper understanding of the trepidation, danger, rejection, and doubt that MLK went through during the Civil Rights Era. It shows a man willing to risk everything for his people, but it also shows a man who questions his approach, and questions his own decisions. SELMA does justice to MLK by showing just how hard a life like his would be, and how hard it was for him to keep choosing to live it when he wasn't being forced to.

Selma is a heavy-handed piece of history, loaded with awkward exposition and a distractingly uneven pace. Too often, it pumps the brakes to fumble character moments or remind viewers of things they should already know from either history or the dialogue from two minutes ago. But when David Oyelowo's MLK goes up to the microphone, or whenever shit remotely approaches the fan, Selma lights up and becomes rather incredibly engrossing in ten minute spurts, with Ana DuVernay taking absolute control of your attention. It's a shame it can't keep it up for the whole running time, but admirably Selma doesn't bite off more than it should chew, restraining itself to one specific campaign rather than telling the story of MLK from birth to assassination (take notes, Imitation Game). Underneath the surface, it leaves serious room from analysis of MLK's tactics, portraying him as just but also media-saavy and not averse to letting his supporters be used as pawns in a larger, more dangerous game. Selma is far from perfect and incredibly flawed as a film, but as a movie, its moments add up to more than its doldrums.Also, "Are you trying to shit me George Wallace?" should immediately become part of the cultural vernacular.

Martin Luther King organizes protests against Alabama's unequal voting laws.One of the best films of the year, Selma features a profoundly affecting performance by David Oleyowo, a wonderful script filled with rousing speeches and perfectly composed scenes, and some interesting directing choices by Ava DeVernay. Oleyowo was certainly robbed of a Best Actor nod as he embodies King's compassion, heroism, and flaws. His rousing speeches, with pitch-perfect delivery, could compel even the most hard-hearted out of his/her chair, and one scene in particular, where King visits the father of a slain protester, is so well-written and well-played, that despite its subdued tenor, still manages to be deeply haunting. DeVernay often frames her actors in the smallest corner of her shots, and while I didn't understand the reason for these choices, I found myself liking her choices.Overall, this is an important film without "insisting upon itself," truly moving and compelling filmmaking.

While this movie is about his time in Selma, and planning the march from Selma to Montgomery, it feels like the filmmakers are trying to cram in as much history behind his entire civil rights movement as they can. David Oyelowo delivers a spellbinding performance as Martin Luther King Jr. in "Selma", an inspiring, powerful and deeply moving film which shines light on a fascinating historical figure. It is an incredibly difficult and daunting task for an actor to bring to life a historical figure who has changed the world. Capturing the way they look, talk and behave- both in public and private- is a backbreaking task for an actor to pull off. When that person is Martin Luther King Jr., arguably one of the most important leaders to ever walk the planet, it's tough. Yet, David Oleyowo, in the performance of a lifetime, has set an example for actors of his generation. From the spot-on Southern accent to the enthusiastic way of delivering a speech, he disappears into the role to the extent that you begin to believe that you're watching Martin Luther King Jr. himself. However, although the center of attention in this drama, he is not the only actor deserving praise. Whether it the emotionally resonant Carmen Ejogo or a perfectly cast Tom Wilkinson, every actor leaves a lasting impression with the viewer. Director Ava DuVernay also deserves recognition for her splendid work behind camera and for having the courage to take on such a larger-than-life time in History. Particularly enthralling are Dr. King's speeches, which are both incredibly inspiring and motivational. Despite Oyelowo's towering transformation, however, the film is not without it's problems. At a running time of over 2 hours, it is not the most well-paced film. Personally, I found myself engaged when the African-Americans were fighting for their rights but not nearly as interested in the presidential politics. Also, despite the power of the performances, Oprah Winfrey is surprisingly wasted. Given her knack for tackling complex roles, she could have been given more to do in this film. In the bigger picture, however, these are minor complaints against a film that is definitely worth watching. Timely for the world we live in today, "Selma" delivers an inspiring message of hope and fighting for what you believe in. Although disturbing to watch at times, it's an important film that demands to be seen for David Oyelowo's breathtaking performance alone.

Let's start with the positives. I had heard from a local rag newspaper (The Boise Weekly) that Oyelowo's performance didn't match the vocal tone and pitch of MLK. Not sure what that means or how someone born after his death would gauge that but it isn't true. Oyelowo does not give a Best Actor performance but he delivers better then anyone else in Hollywood currently. I loved the speeches and I really can't think of anyone else who had both the look and attitude to pull of this role. The emotion of the movie is powerful. Selma really captures the horribly racist attitude of Alabama and the tangible ways in which that was expressed. I liked the supporting cast as well, with the exception of LBJ, who I will get to in a moment. Pretty good soundtrack, although I could imagine a more moving score. On the African-American side, relatively accurate portrayal historically as well. There was a nod to the affair rumors that surrounded King but the movie didn't make the mistake of giving rumors to much screentime or importance. But Selma is far from perfect and in fact, really takes a dive in the face of historical scrutiny. I am quite familiar with the LBJ presidency and Johnson's attitude towards the events of his time. Although his personal feelings may never be known, Johnson's public persona was strongly in support of King's movement, with the president going so far as to publicly bully Congress in order to see results. Portraying Johnson as a weak, indecisive and paranoid leader who stood in the grey in regards to racism is a leap that takes this movie from history to fiction. It would have been completely acceptable to portray Johnson as having to wrestle with some of these actions but the creators of Selma take one of the icons of the Democrat Party, African-Americans and the Civil Rights Movement and turn him into a weakling. To top it off, the movie blatantly ignores the fact that Johnson had the final march escorted by 2,000 soldiers, a move that stands as one of the most blatant government acts against racism since the Civil War. I would really like to say that the movie moves past this mistake, but it doesn't. Unlike other historical blunder movies (Fury being my top choice), Selma simply cannot overcome the weight of its mistakes. And the biggest question in my mind is the why. Johnson was never on the fence. He never did anything publicly to earn the ire of liberals, especially not with the 20/20 vision we have today. To attack him, of all people (Governor Wallace, the KKK and the town leaders are all people who could have been successfully deconstructed without an issue) seems counterproductive, especially in the current context and I think that this is a good indication of DuVernay's future as a director. On top of all of this, the LBJ character wasn't even a great choice and the final scenes of the movie seem to be an about face, as LBJ does what he did historically, in direct opposition to what an hour and half of film just told us. In truth, I think that movies like 12 Years A Slave and even Django Unchained do a better job of pushing for modern day civil rights reform. Selma was a mistake and is a failure to honor all of the dimensions of the story of that march.
This is probably the best civil rights movie ever made. A truly unflinching and raw look at the sheer brutality of the civil rights movement five out of five.

Martin Luther King, Jr.: "When will we be free? Soon and very soon. Because you shall reap what you saw. When will we be free? Soon".Selma tells the story of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. led a dangerous campaign to secure equal voting rights in the face of violent opposition. The epic march from Selma to Montgomery culminated in President Johnson (Tom Wilkinson) signing the Voting Rights Act of 1965, one of the most significant victories for the civil rights movement. Director Ava DuVernays SELMA tells the real story of how the revered leader and visionary Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. (David Oyelowo) and his brothers and sisters in the movement prompted change that forever altered history.Poor Selma, being shut out from the Oscars and BAFTA awards for acting and directing (Which deserves some nominations for god sake) but to be honest I thought this was going to be a Oscar bait film, you know like The Butler or Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close, because I had no idea that this movie existed until award season stared and that's when I had that thought of Oscar bait, but after seeing the film myself I can say no it's not a Oscar bait film. It's actually a pretty good movie.What really surprise me is how much films David Oyelowo has been in 2014, I didn't take much notice but now I have and I was extremely shocked how he got overlooked by the Academy and the BAFTA, because his performance in this movie is by the best I've seen this year. I didn't just see David Oyelowo being Oyelowo, no I only saw Martin Luther King and nothing else. I can see that David Oyelowo had strong passion for this role that he put everything in it and he absolutely nailed it. David you may not got a Oscar nomination for you outstanding performance but you won everyone over with your acting and you got a bright future a head of you buddy. Great work David.Ava DuVernay who to me is a unknown directed. I haven't seen the other work that she did so I can't really say, but after watching Selma I know straight away that we got a good one here, because she directed this movie with has much care as possible and effort to show how bad it was back then and she did it so well her that getting snubbed at the Oscars for directing is crime in my eyes.The one thing that makes Selma a truly great movie is the fact that the movie isn't all inspiring or beautifully touching like most Holly Wood cliche Oscar bait movies, no the director smartly takes a different turn for the best and just show what really happened and try not to make it all inspiring and make Martian look like a god like person and all that other stuff that's been done to death now. Selma steps away from that and shows the mistakes that this guy did because let's not forget that Martian Luther Kings was only human, just a guy who's not perfect of what he did and I hate it when Holly Wood takes a real life person and make him perfect and a god to everybody's eyes and when you look up the person in real life you start to see these other stories where he made mistakes then and there and you find out that the movie isn't being truthfully to the real life person, but in this movie Selma takes that cliche and say "Sorry but that dose not happen. Go away Holly Wood". Now for problems: Martin Luther Kings was the only interesting and the one person I cared about in this movie, but the other character's I didn't really give a fuss about them. I know I should but really I don't, I don't even remember they names at all. You may find them interesting but I didn't.Selma overall isn't just a Oscar bait or too HollyWood movie. The movie has outstanding performances from David Oyelowo, great directing from Ava DuVernay and a movie that I hope get's viewers attention in the late future.

Historical events a must see...

A superb, emotionally exhausting film that effectively portrays the black civil right movement by focusing on the events that occurred within Selma, Alabama. David Oyelowo is Martin Luther King Jr. and is complete perfection. In the film, MLK is not a super-being but is portrayed as a man with some flaws who struggles to balance his family life with his role as a leader. Despite his human weaknesses he is still able to overcome them and emerge as a hero. The film has plenty of hard-hitting moments, and it really puts you through the wringer. The film also has great supporting performances by Tim Roth as Gov. George Wallace, Carmen Ejogo as Coretta Scott King (what a strong, inspiring character. Crazy to think she was last seen in The Purge Anarchy as the mother), Oprah Winfrey as Annie Lee Cooper, Tom Wilkonson as President Lyndon B. Johnson (who is not portrayed here as a bad guy but as a coward who chooses to remain neutral in the conflict and in doing so causes more harm), Giovanni Ribisi as Lee White, Dylan Baker as J. Edgar Hoover, Cuba Gooding Jr. as Fred Gray, and Martin Sheen as Frank Minis Johnson. This is a heartbreaking, and angering film. It's hard to believe we ever lived in a time where these kinds of terrible things happened and were allowed and even encouraged. It's a stark reminder of some of the USA's dark history, and that even though we have come so far the battle is still not over. An absolute must-see and not only one of the best films of 2014, it's also one of the most important.

Another way over hyped flick. Nothing we didn't know already and you just went with the flow. It was like watching film you had seen already and throughout I just wanted to see Alan Parker's 'Mississippi Burning'. In saying that it is enjoyable and worth watching alone for the performances of Tim Roth as George Wallace, Tom Wilkinson as President Johnson and David Oyelowo as Martin Luther King, Jnr.

I really liked the director's view over the facts and all. All the bridges scenes are really moving, the first one made me really emotional. Overall, I would say David Oyelowo delivers a great performance, really standing out from the rest of the cast, even though he tends to sound like he's giving the "I have a dream" speech during the entire movie.I don't know if Mr MLK Jr. was that formal all the time, or if that is simply his way of talking, anyway. For me, the movie fulfills its purpose very well.
Selma was on my see list for big screen, but it has produced sour grapes from its director and has pitted itself against American Sniper. This was a mistake for Selma. I may see it later. May not.

I almost didn't like this one, just based on the fact that the dialogue here is mostly pretty boring to sit through. It does have some pretty inspiring things to say in this event of history and the performances here are all top notch. But as for being one of the top films of the year and something I one would want to sit through again, I would say no. This is the type that was made for history classes in school and not something to be marveled as a masterpiece of film itself as most critics would say. The soundtrack, I believe is what saved this movie and David Oyelowo's portrayal mostly. For those interested in the full story of what happened at Selma, I would recommend this to, otherwise it's more of a rental than anything.

Selma manages to soar high above the typical oscar-nom-inspirational-biopic through its mix of emotional subtleties and shocking brutality. I consistently sobbed from start to finish (barely even an exaggeration) - the cinematography, performances, and raw emotional power were truly overwhelming.
Glad to see this film skyrocket to the 6th rank in Best of RT
Apart from a few historical flaws. This movie was excellent full of passion and emotion! Very difficult to watch, but very inspirational!

Flawed but unquestionably noble, the power of Selma resides almost entirely in its message. It can be a difficult task analyzing a film you so passionately agree with, but in Selma's overwhelming flood of acclaim, I can't help but feel an honest examination of its imperfections has been lost in the shuffle. David Oyelowo's spirited performance commands respect, admiration, and enthusiastic praise, but the film stumbles elsewhere in its otherwise unremarkable characterizations. In examining merely one event, director Ava Duvernay occasionally stumbles into over-simplicity, providing a single full-bodied persona surrounded by a host of half-measures. Most disappointing is the general scarcity of Carmen Ejogo as Coretta Scott King, whose talents are criminally underused and had me craving for more. Tom Wilkinson gives a fine performance as Lyndon B. Johnson, but one can hardly call it penetrating. Tim Roth as the racist Governor George Wallace doesn't fare as well with his cartoonish drawl and one-note evilness. These are small detractors ultimately, ignored though they be. However, while not perfect, Selma is still an important enough film to recommend on a wide scale. It is a film with the power to unite, and conjure up the better aspects of our human nature. It's a healthy film, and essential.

With this movie, director Ava DuVernay crafts a remarkable feat of telling the story of the protest marches in Selma, Al in 1965 that resulted in the historic Voting Rights Act from as many points of view as possible while keeping the issues that are still relevant front and center through some electric debate scenes. At the focus of the action is Dr. Martin Luther King(David Oyelowo, who is superb). But this not St. Martin we are talking about here. Rather, what we get is a rather human interpretation, with King having serious doubts and haunted by thoughts of mortality. So, it is no wonder that at the moment of his greatest triumph, namely about to be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, he confides to his wife Coretta(Carmen Ejogo) about the possibility to start over at a country parish. But even then, he still goes on to serve as an inspiration to so many, with the film also recognizing the acts of everyday courage and heroism that took to make the marches possible.Where "Selma" falters is in the White House scenes and not in the way you may have been led to believe. Aside from the specifics, on the one hand, you can see the beginning of the rift between King and President Johnson(Tom Wilkinson) that would widen as Vietnam would consume Johnson's presidency and which war King would oppose vociferously. At the same time, these scenes are undermined by a woefully miscast Wilkinson who can never quite get the right Texan intonation. And the referred to, but never seen White House demonstrations, only serve to have the movie's modest budget serve as a distraction.

All the Hollywood "glitz" that gets wasted on VFX junk food gets put to great use here. Historical controversies aside (really, if the biggest thing was a less than completely flattering portrayal of LBJ, I think we're going to be okay), this was a really great movie. I was gripped every moment of it, and *that is exactly what should happen*. This is an amazing story and David Oyelowo's performance is stunning, not overacted like Steve Carrell in Foxcatcher or Benedict Cumberbatch in The Imitation Game. It is a crime that Oyelowo didn't get nominated for an Oscar for his performance.

I've been putting off seeing Selma until today, for obvious reasons. On the day we celebrate the man himself, it only seemed right see his life celebrated on film. Selma finally brings Martin Luther King to the screen. A proper look at the life of one of America's greatest heroes was long overdo. Making a movie is relatively easy, making a good one is much harder. But Selma, most certainly, is a good one.There has been much controversy of late about the film's lack of recognition at the Academy Awards. Most egregiously, David Oyelowo's stirring performance as King was overlooked. I'll be the first to agree that 2014 has had more than enough unbelievable performances, but is Oyelowo's one of the five best of the year? Absolutely. It is one of the most grounded, impassioned, and impactful performances 2014 has to offer. The film's greatest challenge is portraying MLK correctly, and portraying him well. I am more than happy to say that David Oyelowo succeeds at every facet of this performance. It is obvious that the portrayal, much like the man, is anchored in a very quiet, spiritual strength. Oyelowo is on record as saying, "I always knew that in order to play Dr. King, I had to have God flow through me because when you see Dr. King giving those speeches, you see that he is moving in His anointing." The actor is a powerhouse, proudly marching in Martin Luther King's shoes.The second most prominent rebuff this film received at the Oscars is for its director, Ava DuVernay. I can understand the outcry. The Academy has never been kind to female directors, and nominating an African American female director would be a first. But at the same time, I do not feel like DuVernay's work is Oscar worthy. There are some noticeable filmmaking slip-ups (ignoring the 180-degree rule entirely during the jail-house talk, for example) that do detract from the overall experience. Don't misunderstand, this is an impressive film. But on the waiting list of directors who deserved to be nominated for an Oscar this year, DuVernay is definitely behind Dan Gilroy, Christopher Nolan, and Damien Chazelle.Selma absolutely excels when the main performances are allowed to shine. There are a myriad of talented actors represented in this movie, though many of the supporting characters fail to differentiate themselves from each other, to the movie's detriment.The film has a vast amount of painful, dramatic power. There are multiple scenes that are truly difficult to watch. The filmmakers nail the sense of injustice that is pointed against the peaceful protestors of Selma. The movie also doesn't alienate its white audience (myself among them) by painting with too broad a brush. There can't help but be a sense of accomplishment when protestors of both races join in the march toward freedom.Selma does an awful lot right. The performances are praiseworthy no matter where you look, the story is easily one that needed to be told, and the script provides for a powerful look at a man who deserves to be celebrated. The film won't find its way into my top 10 favorites of 2014, it may slip into historical biopic trappings every now and again, the musical score is unfortunately nondescript, and some of the technical aspects of the movie seemed a bit off at times; but the story and messages on display in Selma are more than worthy of all the recognition they continue to receive. The film does not simply demand our respect, it genuinely earns it."We build the path as we can, rock by rock." 7.5/10

In the wake of a certain series of current events that have brought back racial barriers in America, this film couldn't have come at a better time to throw out some good perspective while honoring the late great Martin Luther King Jr during his annual time of recognition. "Selma" plays reference to Selma, Alabama, which was the starting point to an extremely important chapter of the 60s American Civil Rights movement where African Americans peacefully protested for their ability to vote by attempting to march from the small town all the way to the state capital of Montgomery. Dr. King's direct involvement in this war of political and human rights was heralded due to his dedicated ability to stand against what seemed at the time an impossible force. Angry mobs, brutal police retaliation, corrupt officials, J. Edgar Hoover and his goons, even President Eisenhower, each presented a severe form of resistance in this march. Against so many odds, Dr. King and the countless persecuted people he voiced for, took blow after blow and kept on marching until they finally broke through to make another change in racial injustice forever.  The point of the march with the rising publicity of the act during it's time, was directed at raising general awareness and to better expose the dirty secret the powers that be were so poorly keeping under wraps. Half a century later, this behind the scenes expose' further enlightens us as to how much more dire the situation was than even when general media was alluding to. On both sides of the line, we witness a passionate and unwavering group led by Dr. King with all the resolve they could muster, just as we get a play by play of every grueling obstacle that was thrown at them by their white oppressors. Last year's Oscar winner "12 Years A Slave" was a soul crushing roller coaster that really played up the monstrous side of racism during its prime time of America's upbringing. While not as graphic, "Selma" plays to a similar emotional cord and bears importance because unlike "Slave", these events took place during our current life time. It really goes to show how topsy turvy we were as a culture not so long ago, and how truly far we have come in breaking the ultimate barriers. The film as a whole is a wonderful piece of insight that is laid out to glorify the event as SO much more than a march. Up and coming actor David Oyelowo (Interstellar) had some massive resolve of his own in being responsible for portraying the historic figure of Dr. King, and was remarkable in showcasing his powerhouse side just as much he really brought a little seen perspective of Martin, the humble and humane family man. Helped along by his surprisingly British supporting cast, the lot of them bring to life a series of true characters and tell a supremely emotional tale that deserves remembrance. Kudos on a very well done biopic, and happy Martin Luther King Jr day. . .GRADE: A

SELMA is a movie about process, about the gruntwork and strategy and planning and procedure of staging a civil rights campaign, about how change is enacted through through careful swaying of public opinion and deliberate framing of a compelling narrative on TV screens and in newspapers around the country. In a similar way to Spielberg-Kushner's LINCOLN, it's thrilling to see a movie that gets at the practical political mechanics behind an easily romanticized revolution. But, for a movie about strategy and power dynamics to work, it needs, more than anything, the couple of things that hurts SELMA above all.The first of those is subtext. This is a movie almost entirely made up of people standing in rooms explaining what they are going to do. It's historical drama Christopher Nolan-style. It's a problem in the writing and it's a problem in the direction--nowhere is there an inventive variation on the dramatic dynamic to make things interesting. Contrast this with a film like LINCOLN, which is all about how people lie and cheat and make deals and barter and trade and wheel and deal. These are obviously two very different films about two very different sets of characters in two very different sets of circumstances, but it's that lack of subtext, that lack of dramatic layering that keeps the whole thing playing on one level. And, seemingly opposed to this, but actually tied directly to it is the second point...A driving sense of clarity. Clarity in the drama. Clarity in the objectives (both macro and micro) and in the tactics. In the obstacles. In the sense of cause and effect. In each character's particular motivations and where and why and how they clash in any given moment. Clarity in the timeline. Clarity in even something as basic and seemingly irrelevant as screen geography (I'm not sure I've ever seen a movie that crosses the line so frequently or so carelessly, and the lack of establishing shots in almost any scene only adds to the confusion--especially when much of the film plays out in a series of pretty nondescript rooms and curiously-framed, and coldly desaturated medium close-ups). When SELMA has this clarity, it is exciting and engaging--some of the conversations between Dr. King and President Johnson are among the highlights of the film precisely because the negotiation is so thoroughly grounded in such clearly articulated stakes (probably not coincidentally, this subplot is drawing some heat for taking some dramatic license with the events). The finale, aided by some actual documentary footage, is rousing and moving in the way it should be. But there are long stretches that do little to advance the story in actual story terms, content instead to reiterate the same dramatic beats without providing any further context or elaboration. The movie's ambitions are admirable, but it's never as smart as its subject matter, and the result is some often deflated drama. Still, this story is important, and continues to be discouragingly relevant in all kinds of ways. It's a story we need to hear, but I wish it was better told.

The first time a 99% movie on RT has let me down. It's pure sap: slow motion beatings, constant emotional monologues, with the whole made-for-TV inspirational aesthetic thing going on. Plus Oyelowo doesn't seem charismatic enough for the role. Someone needs to make a real MLK movie.
Fantastic movie. Should be required viewing in US high schools.
Great story told well

A riveting, sometimes shocking biopic that takes us into the daily lives of Martin Luther King and his followers, and gets to the roots of the protests in Selma, creating a sense of community and solidarity. Accuracy aside, it's a great work of art, if a little dry and unfocused in places. The performances are excellent - weird though (not wrong or bad) that King, Johnson, and Wallace are all portrayed by non-American actors. From a technical and artistic perspective it's not one of the more atmospheric or creative of 2014's movies, but it is powerful, enthralling, and often surprising, including 2 or 3 of the year's most shocking and effecting scenes (the explosion, the police brutality, and King's speech at the end stand out to me). On paper it might be calling out for awards, but in execution it's the least Oscar-baity of the nominated biopics, focusing more on characterization and on a concise plot than on King's entire life. The film makes it clear to us that it's so much bigger than King, allowing him to be central to its plot without raising him to the level of a god or showing us that he was in any way more important than his movement. Though I don't think it will go down as a great work of art or an accurate portrayal of history (films based on other material, in my opinion, don't need to be accurate to be good) I think it's a film we should celebrate as great in-the-moment cinematic storytelling, resonant with a struggle that still continues to this day.

Oyelowo was very good in the lead role and the supporting cast did a good job. The movie overall was a good history lesson, however - it was very slow at times. Some of the more biopic drama with King's family just went on too long. People talking slowly and softly in dark rooms with dramatic lighting gets old after a while, just like it did in Million Dollar Baby.

Overrated and overhyped, Selma is a made for TV movie that has been given far more credit than it has earned. The real problem is that it is a well-acted slideshow of history, rather than a cohesive story. Monologues are the name of the game here and while I do enjoy a good monologue or two of self-awareness, here it just got annoying as it was hard to relate to characters who most of the time speak in monologues rather than as people.American History X did a much better job of exploring the themes of racism and hate while still maintaining a genuine (and very tragic) character story.
David Oyelowo gives an amazing performance as Dr King, but overall, Selma is a pretty average movie. Not bad, but not great.
So Good! So relevant to our times, sadly. Great depiction of the decade. Great acting. and if Johnson had sounded as good as the actor playing him, he would have been way more popular.

While it wasn't among my favorite movies of the year, I can still recognize how important a well-made movie like Selma is. Ava DuVernay tells a memerizing story and David Oyelowo gives a dramatic portrayal as Martin Luther King, Jr. History books can make monumental events seem so impersonal, so I appreciate films like these that show how much had to be overcome to get to where we are today. The movie has several uncomfortable but powerful moments, and in some ways, it also reminds me that while our society has progressed a lot since then, we still have a long way to go.

Very good. Entertaining and powerful except David Oyelowo didn't really remind me of MLK. I believed his performance in telling this story, but MLK had one of the most distinctive voices you can have. It does't take away from the film, but it seems pretty obvious that nailing MLK's vocal cadence would have sealed the Best Actor nod. Anyway fat ignorant white people in power still suck. Sad how little has changed.

Really great film that should be seen by everyone. The Selma story is one that doesn't get a much play, but is as much an important story of our civil rights history of any. See this one with the kids, it is really amazing!
Excellent! Clearly portrayed the behind the scenes culmination of efforts, progression to get to the final Selma march.

This may step on a lot of toes, but I was not crazy about Selma. Granted, this is a movie that should have been made long ago, and coincided perfectly with the turmoil created by the police shootings; I was not impressed. The first half of the movie discussed the politics and legal wrangling involved in the march. I felt that Martin and Coretta's characters were underdeveloped, and needed more fleshing out. How did Martin's absence affect the children? Why did Coretta put up with the cheating? Okay, but not worth buzz.

Captivating true story overdue to be told on screen, held together by a spot on performance by David Oyelowo as Martin Luther King Jr. The story's content is monumental and inescapably informative. Oyelowo has King pegged on every gesture, voice tone, and mannerism. He even captures King's astonishing speech delivery. We see MLK as a human being who is vulnerable, asking himself questions: Is this the best way? Is this the right place and right time? He weighs the options of putting people in harm's way vs achieving the objective. He's not an unstoppable superhero activist who has a clear path and a surefire plan. He's a conflicted man who is figuring out the best way to proceed as he goes along. The brutal violence against peaceful demonstrators is light on gory detail but puts a spotlight on the brutality, which is shockingly hateful. Police on horseback armed with clubs and tear gas charge into a crowd of defenseless marchers. Aged men and women are struck repeatedly in the head with police clubs, even when lying still on the ground. A young man goes to shield his grandfather from being beaten by police, and for this he is thrown against the wall and shot in front of his mother. The three officers depart as the mother cries out. This was only 50 years ago in this very country. You don't forget this is a true story. Use of actual footage from these very events and the scenes introduced by actual FBI logs of King's activities appearing to the sound of a typewriter keep everything grounded in reality. A couple stylistic changes might have made the film stronger. I wish the extended scenes of quiet discussions did not so frequently interrupt the suspenseful urgency of planning and carrying out the protests. While perhaps serving as an oasis for some, I felt it anticlimactic. Dr King's internal struggles could have been developed in more punctuated scenes. Nevertheless, this is a powerful film that perhaps all Americans should see.
Amazing performances, directing, cinematography... everything. The lack of nominations is incredibly upsetting.

Wonderful portrait of the exciting months leading to the march from Selma to Montgomery with a brilliant David Oyelowo as the main character but also very good support acting. Intense without being cheesy.

Selma's strength is focusing on events leading up to a particular moment, rather than attempting to summarize King's entire life into what presumedly would have been a rushed and disjointed biopic. The cast is great, but Oyelowo completely transforms. And the film is shot with such beauty and restraint that at times it fools you into thinking you're watching the actual events unfold. The movie is as timeless as its central figure.

Harrowing, suspenseful, and featuring an Oscar worthy performance from David Oyelowo, Selma is one of the years best. A wonderful story, Selma presents Martin Luther King as we have never seen him portrayed before...as a man, flaws and all.
Excellent...powerful.
Good history movie, sometimes a little boring. Very good acting.

Selma se resume en una palabra, poderosa. Ava DuVernay captura muy bien el esfuerzo y las luchas del pueblo negro y lo transmite al pblico con sencillez y sin tener que exagerar nada. David Oyelowo da la mejor actuacin de su carrera en la cual se transforma en el Dr. King con suma perfeccin. Muy bien editada y dirigida, es una pelcula que se debe ver casi obligatoriamente.
A moving and poignant American story, with universal significance highlighting injustice. (Curiously starring mostly Brits)
Amazing film; really powerful and moving, great acting, music, and cinematography.

A story of conviction that fuels the fire of justice and righteousness -- Selma soars high above the rest. The film excels on multiple fronts in the name of justice, whether it be social, political, or otherwise. The message is clear, concise, and divulged to the audience through raw emotion and passion.The leader of that emotion and passion comes from the highly spirited performance from David Oyelowo as Dr. King. Oyelowo brings King to life and does a fantastic job of showing the layers of the person beyond the struggle during the Civil Rights Movement. The personal and social dilemmas are vital to the story of who King was an not only an activist, but as a man, and that is brought to the forefront by Oyelowo.The film produced some wonderful cinematography... Different shots of the various marches or the manner in which the violence was captured, for example, transform this into a piece of art. With that said, I did find the film to be slightly longer than I felt necessary. It seemed like Selma could have been even more powerful if it left a few scenes on the chopping room floor to shorten the length just slightly. The musical and sound arrangements were well produced and organized, and it is fair to say that Selma is well deserving of every award or nomination it may get. There is a bit of a fury regarding the lack of nominations, but there is no need to get into an uproar... Good things happen to those who exhibit patience and peacefully revolt against what they believe to be unjust.

Oscars got it right...not a good movie. How can you have murder, politics, and racism seem so mundane? And rap music???? common, shameful. Not an exciting movie, not gripping, very underwhelming. Pacing bad, cinematography bad. No fire in the actors...Oprah was the best part of the movie, and the end where they tell you what happened to the characters.Watch "Malcom X" instead. Million times better and more information and better performances.
Awesome! Excellent acting and directing. Very moving.

We've all seen and heard his speeches. To finally see him and his principles in action is quite the cathartic experience. Director Ava DuVernay (who is the first black female director nominated for Best Director at the Golden Globes) orchestrates a solid, well-put-together ensemble that sings Glory and reverberates the continued march in the fabric of our lives.

Hum... Sometimes you read a true story and it is so moving you just can't imagine a movie doing it justice. Well, Clint Eastwood on American Sniper delivers brilliantly and Spike Lee on Malcolm X killed it. Why did the people who wanted to bring Selma to the big screen not call upon Spike Lee? What in the world where they thinking? I seriously thought this was another Angelina Jolie directed movie because it had the same look and feel as the butcher job that was done on another powerful story like Unbroken. I say redo, but please give the directing of these great stories to people that truly have a vision and skill to do the stories justice. Kinda mad cuz I love Martin Luther King.
Poor acting, questionable accuracy, at best.

Wow. Selma is a powerful film and one that resonates in our current times where racial tensions between authorities and the people have been stirred once again. Selma follows Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. as he leads a peaceful campaign for the voting rights of black people in Alabama. David Oyelowo is fantastic, his speeches given in Dr. King's astounding tone and his roller-coaster of emotions in the face of constant adversity are memorable. I think that everyone needs to see this movie no matter their color, to see people white and black marching together for freedom and equality. In the end the movie proves that there is no "them" there is only US.

This film should be essential viewing for all schools history classes. Powerful performances by the entire cast. It's hard to say in words just how fantastic this film is. David Oyelowo recreates Dr King is such a perfect way showing his greatness as well as his faults.
Powerful movie! A reminder from our recent past of why inequality in this country can not abide!

"Selma" pieces together several scenes of monumental moments in American black civil rights history. The performances are no more than adequate and the characters are left undeveloped, leaving a disjointed film that's trying too hard to emulate a Best Picture instead of innovating enough to be one. The story itself, however, is so moving that it's almost impossible to not feel its emotional power.

Saw Selma on MLK Day because it made sense to do. Amazing performances by all actors to show the complexities of the time. I cried for the pain and suffering that was endured by blacks with whites in solidarity to secure their right to vote. I cried for all these leaders who were murdered during this decade. I cried that the SCOTUS weakened the 1965 Voting Rights Act to keep people from voting democratic party. ?#?historic?

Absolutely one of the most inspiring and important movies I have ever seen. The acting is unbelievable and the choices of what to share and what to skip just seem perfect. Wow. This is an American history lesson found nowhere else, and yet so absolutely critical to creating a better world. Every student should be required to see this film.
Best movie of the year.

I really wanted to like Selma, but it just missed the mark for me. For starters, very few of the characters were formally introduced, so their story or names for that matter weren't well known until the end of the movie when they flashed their names with a bio. Also, the police report-style text that came after some scenes really didn't seem to have much of a purpose or fit in with what was going on in the movie, and it wasn't ever explained why it was shown. Besides that, the movie was very slow-moving with a lot of awkward silence that just added to its longevity. Overall, Selma just didn't do justice to its important subject matter and it felt unfinished. It just needed a little more clarity and cohesion to be a good movie.
Another tragedy of the awards season. How Ooyelowo has been overlooked for a best actor nomination in favour of Cooper, Keaton, Cumberbatch and Carrell god only knows.

An emotional and intellectual movie on this 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King. We were lucky to visit his childhood home, Ebenezer Baptist Church and his eternal flame when we had a few hours in Atlanta in January.

Having grown up in Alabama, living through these unbelievable events as a child, it is powerful to watch this critically important time in our countries history in film. Well produced, directed and acted story of one of the world great leaders and change agents.

Excellent and important movie. David Oyelowo is impressive as MLK. (Quite a feat to convincingly portray an international, well-known icon.) Oprah by contrast should have taken a pass. Despite her believable portrayal of a supporting character... well, she's Oprah! Every time she appeared on the screen, even as a face in the crowd, my head goes, "Oh, there's Oprah again." (which of course makes derails the scene ). The Oprah distraction tells me how far we've come. A black American woman is one of the most recognizable people on the planet and universally loved and respected for her social intelligence.Selma is a mover well worth seeing. Rates #2 on my list of Best Pictures, behind The Imitation Game.

A deftly-directed, plotted and acted biopic of the trailblazing Martin Luther King Jr, who was an instrumental figure in advancing the African-American Civil Rights Movement. Selma charts King's involvement in the 1965 historic marches that sought for voting rights for the blacks. The psychological ordeals and injustices the marchers have to go through are compelling yet utterly heartbreaking. But the true star is David Oyelowo as the charismatic and unshakeable King. In this blessed modern age where we're beset with indifference, one only wishes there're more of such selfless, strong, inspirational and motivational leaders around. Someone with a spine, mind and heart.

As we left the theater I overheard someone's opinion that film should be shown in every middle school in America. That's exactly my problem. America and particularly African-Americans deserve a truthful presentation of these momentous events. I get it that Blacks won these achievements for themselves, but was it necessary to portray Johnson as contemplating King's murder, mouthing the n-word, yucking it up with George Wallace and having the Voting Rights Act (which he ordered written the night he won election to the Presidency) shoved down his throat? Preposterous and shameful! A beautiful and important movie that should be watched by everyone. It's too bad the filmmakers found it necessary to dumb it down and defame allies of the movement to simplify the plot.

David Oyelowo is a tremendous Martin Luther King but beyond his performance the film falls a little flat. No doubt the picture and the piece of history it portrays is very worthy but as coverage of a specific period it lacks a bit of climax and punch.
This movie not only captivates your attention, but it is also incredibly accurate according to what happened in history.

Very good movie, but not great. I'd rather watch the great documentaries and hear form the real people who were there. Southern Poverty Law Center and PBS have much better movies on the subject. Just because Oprah is in it, doesn't make it better than those who were there speaking for themselves.

David Oyelowo's performance as Martin Luther King is fiercely powerful and emotional yet remains true and real throughout. When this performance combines with a well written script, it makes for a memorable film.

I vote "Yes" for "Selma" as a quality biographical movie, and that is my cinematic civil right to do so. Now I will try to be civil as much as possible, but I liked this movie better when it was called "Lincoln". I am kidding! Please don't start the protest. All kidding aside, "Selma" is an important piece of filmmaking that chronicles Dr. Martin Luther King's campaign to secure equal voting rights via an epic march from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama in 1965. Like "Lincoln", "Selma" is the kind of movie that should be shown to every high school student in their American History class. Director Ava DuVernay might just be marching on to more directorial gigs with her accurate orchestration of the picture. Paul Webb's screenplay of "Selma" marched on to the applicable verbal beat of the story it was telling. Oye esto, David Oyelowo was majorly snubbed of a Best Actor Oscar nomination for his triumphant performance as Dr. King. I don't want to get too political but Tom Wilkinson and Tim Roth pitched in with solid supporting performances, respectively as President Lyndon B. Johnson and Governor George Wallace. Now, "Selma" is not a "I have a dream of a perfect movie" type of film, but I still think you should march on to it. **** Good

Incredibly moving and almost poetic recreation of the months leading up to the historic march from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama in support of voting rights and the greater civil rights movement. David Oyelowo is almost Shakespearean in his delivery of King's various speeches and eulogies and in his quiet moments of despair, including a late night call to the singer Mahalia Jackson in an effort to fortify himself. This is powerful, powerful stuff and in light of what's been happening in the U.S. the past few years, not just in Ferguson and with the NYPD, but in the shameful treatment of the President and the continuing effort to discourage voting in the South, this movie might capture the zeitgeist better than any made before it. I always remember hearing about German citizens being marched by American soldiers through the now-emptied concentration camps that were near enough to their towns and villages to be smelled and occasionally dusted with the soot of burned remains. They were forced to witness what was done in their name. I still believe the American public needs that moment, as a people they have still never come to grips with their original sin. Great films like "12 Years A Slave" and now "Selma" will hopefully hold up that mirror and even if the people only see their reflection in a corner, at least its a start. Required viewing, in my opinion.

I didn't love Selma though it was far from bad. The acting is fantastic, the story is very interesting, upsetting,and heartbreaking, and the look of the film is very well done (especially in the scenes regarding the bridge crossings). MLK's public speeches are generally quite powerful, but when it comes to the private meetings his words start to feel contradictory, wishy washy, and some ideas don't seem fully realized. These talks even start to feel stale at parts. And while it is a part of the film, MLK's family interaction is underdeveloped.And while the history behind Selma is important for every American to know about I just didn't think this film was all that great.And boy, do you really hate LBJ while watching this film. Well, until the scene with his sudden, random, uncharacteristic change of heart.

Selma is a triumph of a film worthy of representing one of the most influential moments in American history. DuVernay depicts Martin Luther King, not as the immovable giant we are accustomed to but rather the man who will eventually blossom into that figure. The journey taken by DuVernay is that of portraying King as a man with the weight of a Nobel Peace Prize around his neck. The film equally uncovers the emotions of the people of Selma and ultimately those of the nation.  David Oyelowo plays the role of a lifetime in this portrayal of Kings pursuit of human dignity and unity. Although we are privy to brief glimpses of King preaching to the masses, the story focuses on the quiet struggles of leadership as well as his suffering for decisions made in life-or-death situations with little information. The powerful interactions between Oyelowo and Carmen Ejogo ignite the screen and allow for an intimate glimpse into the private life of the King family through all their hardships and uncertainties.  A beautifully written story with an incredible ensemble of supporting cast has created this definitive account of the events of Selma. This is a story not about the victories of the past or the fame of the man but rather the work ahead. This film not only paints a picture of the racial injustice of the sixties but forces one to look at the racial injustices becoming weekly occurrences during recent years and even months. The message of this film becomes clear that even with a 99% reaction from critics, an outstanding lead, and an incredible ensemble of support cast, this film was only nominated for two Oscars that do not focus on the cast itself, Best Picture and Original Song. The question King must grapple with is what is the body count in which King is obligated and burdened to sacrifice to progress the movement?

David Oyelowo puts on an impressive performance, showing both Dr. King's impressive dedication to the cause,as well as his human side. Ava DuVernay weaves a very tense epic, demonstrating the viciousness of the violence against those fighting for civil rights, as well as the difficulty of managing a non-violent movement composed of so many different people. Alas, the movie would have been far better served with more historical accuracy. The changes served to detract from the incredible story, rather than enhance it. Unnecessarily making a villain of Lyndon B. Johnson didn't really serve the story any more than the truth. Heightening the tension between the SCLC and SNCC was also unnecessary and distracting. But don't let it's intentional ignorance of history prevent you from seeing it; there is still a lot to like here.

Positive depictions of LBJ be damned, finally a mainstream film that addresses an important moment in the Civil Rights moment from a predominately black perspective and does so without too much sentimentality. Oyelowo is great as King and DuVernay's direction announces her as a major talent.

Even as it celebrates hard-won progress, "Selma" is a humbling reminder that there is still a long way to go in the fight for equality and justice.

I'm rather shocked that this is the first major movie that follows the life of Martin Luther King Jr. But thankfully due to steady and Skilled direction and fantastic performances, Selma becomes one of the best movies to cone out last year. We all know the story of Dr king but the movie shows that there's more to this story. What really brings Selma to greatness is its performances, for his breakout performance, David Oyelowo becomes Dr King, all the mannerisms, the voice, the actions down perfectly, but he also brings humanity to him showing that he's also just a man with his heart in the right. I'm shocked that he wasn't nominated for best actor. But I have to respond to the controversy with the scenes involving president Johnson, He's not portrayed as a bad guy, the give him reasons and it makes sense, the rest of the acting is fantastic. The direction is tight and shows huge amounts of details making this one of the most violent and raw pg-13 movies I've seen but, DuVernay was horribly snubbed for the best director nomination. The dialogue is fantastic as well, every character is given a strong amount of depth and humanity showing the reasons of why they act, it also shows the the historical events and facts in very smart ways. Surprised it took this long to get an MLK movie to the big screen, but at least the one that ended up being made was as good as this, it shows in detail all the brutality MLK and his supporters endured down in Selma, and also shows the many sides of MLK, Oyelowo is great here, showing him as a leader giving rousing speeches and leading the marches, also as a family man, relaxing with his friends, and emotional scenes with his wife over his infidelities, Roth is very good as the evil George Wallace, and always good to see fellow south sider Common acting (and singing the end credits song) Hopefully this will serve as launching point for Oyelowo and director DuVernay for long careers, as both are very talented

This movie is called Selma, NOT "The Martin Luther King Jr. Story", for a reason. The intensity and significance of the Civil Rights movement is captured all through one seemingly small, but ultimately huge, demonstration. And while King's a more than prominent part of this story, and is even the de facto protagonist, Selma was a victory for more than one individual, and DuVernay and co. know that. With a beautiful lead performance by Oyelowo, this is stirring and engrossing dramatic filmmaking that humanizes history and an icon, embracing every part of the ugly truth.Selma doesn't rely on lazy-biopic gimmicks to catch us up to speed. The filmmakers rightly assume a basic knowledge of King and his impact. This gives the story room to breathe, letting the depth of details and emotions hold the screen over dry facts. We get to see the heartbreak of the injustice up-close, the politicking of all reigning parties (including a fascinating look at the White House), the fear and difficulty inherent in true non-violent protests, and the ultimate hope of goals reached. The script has a few dull moments that could've hit the editing room floor, and some of the casting could be seen as stereotypes, but there is intentionality to director DuVernay's subtly dusty yet intensely personal film.Really, it's hard not to feel personal about Selma, given the state of current racial unrest. We are far from past the teachings of Dr. King, but a devastating-yet-forward-looking film like this can help us learn to see the complexity inherit and necessity in justice. Selma isn't emotionally manipulative; it is emotionally necessary.

The film does have a few pacing issues and it maybe a bit too long, but the film will still stay with you thinking about this great man and his dream.

An emotional juggernaut of a picture, Selma just happens to be another exceptional 2014 biopic, further proving to hopefully not only myself but many others that films of this genre are not just empty and sentimentally-devoid Oscar-bait pictures, but genuinely good motion pictures. Headed by one of the finest and moving performances of the past year, Selma tells the story of Martin Luther King Jr's struggle to gain voting rights for Alabama (and general American) Negroes with respect, heart and dignity, and never stumbles for too long, even in its least satisfying and compelling moments, those of which there are few. Director Ava Duvernay handles the delicacy of the topic at hand with ease, her graceful influence on the film paramount in both its most glorious and triumphant moments, as well as within scenes of intimacy which showcase the humanity inside a man revered by many. But it's ultimately the screenplay, penned by the exceptional Paul Webb, which allows Selma to enter and traverse numerous concepts and ideas, tones and moods, flowing through them oh-so effortlessly, without feeling structurally bound by convention or genericisms. The result of the picture is to an extent predictable (because it happened; duh), but it's the journey there that Webb expertly crafts, a journey that shan't be forgotten soon.Selma's heart comes in its depiction of Martin Luther King Jr, who is painted here not as a saint, but as a human man, capable of failure, deceit and misfortune. His path to success is riddled with desperation, despair, pain and blood, and whilst the outcome of the picture is radiant and triumphant, we, alongside our protagonist, can not help but reflect on the darkness faced all throughout. The great thing about Selma is that it often allows us moments of contemplatation, and allows us to think on what has been suffered. In a moment of monumental and ingenious filmmaking within a poignant scene, Duvernay holds the bravest and most powerful shot of the film. She doesn't allow the score to intervene, nor does she desire a close-up. This is in a scene of gloom, right after a brutal murder is depicted. A mother screams out in anguish as her beautiful and helpless son dies in her arms. Duvernay does not feel obligated to leech the emotion of the scene with unnecessary camera angles, cuts or music. She understands the primal sympathy that we all, universally, feel. So she allows the single shot to play out, and what we feel is pure and utter emotion. It was this shot and the scene which played out after such that brought me to tears.Cinematographer Bradford Young, who also simultaneously worked on A Most Violent Year, heads the photography department of the film, and his work is astounding. His framing is pitch-perfect (the vast majority of the time), his visceral foreshadowing of events or shots is applaudable, and he never bows to the cliches that many would expect of such a film as this in a visual context. No, Young does not consistently frame King at a low angle, accenting his prowess as a human being and activist. He does utilize a strange quantity of hand-held camera work that does seem unnecessary in a number of scenes, but isn't overtly distracting; at least not for the casual viewer, I would imagine. His pans also feel relatively unneeded; perhaps when King is delivering something important, so as to add a strain of visual dynamic to the scene, it is required. But often, this is not the case, and the pans feel a little too much. All that said, Young's work is absolutely stellar on the whole, and his work is some of the finest of 2014. He captures the size of the marches Martin King leads, the intimacy between King and his wife Coretta and the boldness of King's speeches. His versatility is applaudable, and his colour palette is appreciated (thank God the filters from The Theory of Everything weren't utilized here).There are moments of melodrama which feel oddly out of place in a film so concerned with the quiet nature of things. A scene towards the beginning of the running time that shows a black hate crime is not only completely out of place, edited in sloppily, but also ends with a generic dash of slow motion and jarring loudness. It's really quite terrible. Fortunately, the rest of the picture is mostly devoid of such moments, but even with their minimal quantity, their impact is still felt. Perhaps the biggest fault within the running time is the editing, done by Spencer Averick. His work for much of the film is acceptable, but there are moments where he not only sacrifices coherency in the visceral sense, but abruptly ends scenes that do not feel completed. A scene featuring King debating against the president at the time, Lyndon B. Johnson, is cut oddly short in what seems like the middle of a sentence, and it throws off the tightened speed of the picture. This happens numerous times throughout, and it is infuriating.Wow; I feel like I am absolutely shitting all over Selma. In all reality, I truly adored this film. It is an exceptional cinematic achievement that I was engrossed in all throughout its two hour length. This is namely due to the efforts of David Oyelowo as Martin King, whose performance is absolute perfection. He handles the speeches, personal conflictions and emotion of his character perfectly, and it's impossible to fault him in any way. The fact that he was denied a nomination from the Academy for Best Actor enrages me, as he wholeheartedly deserves to be nominated over Michael Keaten in Birdman, or Bradley Cooper in American Sniper. He was truly sensational in every single sequence of film he was in. The rest of the supporting cast feels relegated to smaller roles, unfortunately, and outside of King, we don't get a whole heap of development in terms of the rest of the ensemble. That said, those who make appearances give exceptional performances, whether or not their characters are given as much time to shine as they probably deserve. Opera Winfrey excels as Annie Lee Cooper, and her initial scene is one of the finest of her career. Full of despair and contained enragement, it is a potent way to introduce us to her character. Henry G. Sanders also delivers the most powerful singular scene in the film, his heartbreak shared by the audience in the film's most pivotal moment.This is a beautifully made film. It's far from perfect, but it is all the same riveting, compelling, heartfelt, somewhat unpredictable and always affecting. It does not shy away from the brutality of the era, and the brutality inflicted upon the blacks by the whites. It features an interesting concoction of music, performance, editing and cinematography, and delivers in a visceral sense far more so than other biopics released this year. It's also commendable to see a director within a film of the likes of this utilizing a score which contains thematic consistency and instrumental variety, unlike numerous other scores for films of the likes of this. For example, Hans Zimmer's work for 12 Years A Slave last year was minimalist, derivative, unoriginal drivel, that was not only entirely unemotional, but also immensely underused. McQueen seemed afraid to accent emotions with music. Duvernay, a director who comes off as brave all throughout, is not so scared, and consistently utilizes her score, composed by Jason Moran, to great effect. This kind of bravery to attempt things not otherwise attempted in films of this like is commendable, and whilst she suffers faults throughout (some of them major, others not so much), she earns herself an admirable rating due to the heartfelt emotion, acting prowess, quality cinematography and screenplay on offer. Deserving of its Best Picture nomination.

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr's march from Selma, Alabama to Montgomery gets the biopic treatment in the new film Selma, a movie that does get a lot of things right, but never achieves the greatness that it could have. With recent events in America revolving around racial tension, a movie like this seems aptly timed. The story here is all about what Martin Luther King Jr. did to overcome a very violent and racist time in the town of Selma, Alabama to reach equality in voting rights in Selma. This movie does sport great performances, a solid story, and some very violent moments that hone in on what made this such a monumental moment during the Civil Rights movement. Lets start out with the parts the film gets right. David Oyelowo plays Martin Luther King Jr. in the film and he does an outstanding job here. He delivers on all fronts and there is a single shot in the film where he looks just like King. We also see Common, Wendell Pierce, and Carmen Ejogo deliver fine performances as well as MLK's friends and wife. Tom Wilkinson, Stephen Root, and Tim Roth also deliver as the antagonists of the film making sure that we get a good view of both sides of the conflict. The story here is also handled with care giving credit where credit is due throughout the film and is effectively paced. There are some issues here but more about that later. The direction of the film is also solid with Ava DuVernay adding just the right amount of violence in the storytelling and also making sure the emotional aspects of the film hit home, although it does appear that DuVernay did try and copy the tone of 12 Years a Slave to make her film seem more artistic than it really is. With all these things going so good for this film, there are a few aspects that prevent this from being a great film. The main issue here is the lack of character development. There are indeed a lot of characters here, but the film neglects to tell you who the main supporters are. We do get the mentioning of a few nicknames but that is it. Basically if your name isn't Martin Luther King Jr, you will not get mentioned no matter what your name is. Wendell Pierce has a huge part in the film but they never tell you who he plays, only mentioning in passing he is a Reverend. Not only that but there is some parts of the story that we can't confirm if it actually happened. There are scenes with J. Edgar Hoover and Lyndon Johnson that nobody can even say if it actually happened. Which means that either they made some of the film up just to lean toward one side of the story or they fabricated these events just to make the antagonists more bitter and spiteful. For a film that boasts accuracy, this is just a huge mistake and a giant risk as far as being an actual retelling of the Selma story. There is one very shoehorned character played by Oprah Winfrey that serves no purpose to the story but just to have Oprah be in the film. This isn't a major thing but that just adds on to the argument that this movie made things up to support it's cause. I realize those are bold statements but from where I was sitting, that is how this movie played out for me as a movie goer. All in all Selma is indeed a good movie, albeit a bit overrated. Yes, this film is a solid film that gets a lot of things right and it is easy to see why there is hype for it. However the liberties it takes prevent the film from being a truly great film. I still believe it is worth watching, it is a solid biopic that tells a good story about an event that sometimes gets overlooked in Martin Luther King Jr's career. I'd say this is worth seeing in theaters, might be best as a matinee.
