Everyone has to see this movie. Not because it's the best movie I've ever seen, but because the subject matter is so important. It is especially important in a time of such racial tension.The breathtaking (based on a) true story of a small, but incredibly important, segment of Martin Luther King Jr's civil rights movement. The title, Selma, refers to Selma Alabama. In 1965 King and a large following planned and executed a fifty mile march from Selma to Montgomery Alabama. The performances in Selma are perfect. The story is incredible and even the few slight liberties taken with history can be forgiven for the sake of the narrative.Martin Luther King Jr (David Oyelowo) is a preacher who shoulders the responsibility of trying to improve the social standing of all African-Americans, and all minorities in the United States. King constantly butts heads with President Lyndon B. Johnson (Tom Wilkinson). Johnson has a respect for King, and understands his mission. Selma indicates that Johnson had the power to, at anytime, accomplish what the fifty mile march of the film's climax ultimately would. This is likely true, but Johnson did not want his presidency to be run by someone else. He didn't want his image hurt. Johnson says that he believes King's goal will accomplish itself in due course. He ,Johnson, just doesn't seem to see the severity and importance of taking action on it right away. Johnson isn't painted as a racist. He just doesn't care as much. The real history of the scenario is different, Johnson cared more than he was shown to in the film but it is understandable for the narrative that the dividing line needed to be more black and white, no pun intended.There is a monumental scene in which Malcolm X (Nigel Thatch) and King meet. Two icons in the civil rights movement who had different techniques at accomplishing their goals. The two historic giants settle their differences and show a mutual respect to each other for the greater good.It seems no movie is complete without a villain, in this case the villain is historically accurate which makes him even more terrifying. George Wallace (Tim Roth) is the Governor from Alabama who actively works against civil rights and the Black community. Through Wallace it is clear that King isn't fighting for new laws, he is fighting to have existing laws enforced. African-Americans in the 60s did have the right to vote, nationally. It is a sad fact that this right was denied to them on a state by state, or more local, level.The Selma march itself is the focus of the film, it is not a full biography of King himself. However, the movie does an outstanding job of showing the historical legend as a man. A very human man who shoulders a cause for the good of an entire nation. The portrayal of King by David Oyelowo is perfect. Carmen Ejogo plays King's wife Coretta Scott King. Coretta is a strong and supportive woman but the tension between husband and wife is addressed. With King spending so much time away from home, away from his wife and kids, and on the road with the 60's equivalent of groupies, it makes sense that the wife would be stressed about their situation. The scene between Coretta and Martin is handled with extreme care and executed perfectly.Giovanni Ribisi, Oprah Winfrey, and Wendell Pierce fill out the amazing supporting cast. There are more actors with roles big and small, limited screen time or not that leave quite an impression. For example, Tinity Simone, Mikeria Howard, and Jordan Christina Rice are far from household names. Their screen time was incredibly limited. Credited only as Girl #1, #2, and #3. These young actresses deliver some of the most haunting and effective moments in any movie that came out this year.While the subject matter and performances are absolutely something to be praised the film itself is not without issues. The framing, picture quality, and cinematography were a mess in Selma. Characters were often framed to far parts of the screen, off center, and grainy. The camera bobbed in strange ways and the colors were often so muted it felt like there was a cloud over the lenses on the cameras.Poor cinematography aside, Selma is an important movie. It tells an important piece of history and acts as something of a biography for a man who was larger than life.My thoughts on the "Oscar Snubs"I understand racism is still very real, and I understand there is a lot of racial tension in our country lately. However racism is a serious claim. To say that this movie was locked out of all of the awards purely on race is, in my opinion, taking things too far. I fully believe Oyelowo should have been nominated for best actor. I don't know which of the fantastic actors I would have dropped out of the category in his place however. Plus, isn't dropping one actor just to have a minority actor in the running racist in itself? Furthermore, to say Director Ava DuVernay was "snubbed" is a bit ridiculous. As far as a visual story telling medium goes the visuals were largely ugly and not award worthy.

Selma transports the viewer back in time, 50 years ago. The view we have as we are transported and watch the story unfold may feel eerily relatable and relevant to present day. Gorgeous shots, detailed costume and superb acting make this film an engrossing experience. No matter what your views on race are, you should see this film. Watch with an openness and willingness to reflect and place yourself in the shoes of those depicted in this masterful work.
The most powerfully moving film this year and a masterpiece among historical biopics. Talk about an Oscar snub... Selma beats out Boyhood for best picture, hands down, in my humble opinion.

Selma reminds us that time is indifferent to equality and justice, and that change can only occur when action is taken. So stop complaining about your politicians and go and do something, you lazy bastard. In all, the film is as slow paced as a march, treading on through its plot. Luckily, this helps to punctuate the drama caused by police brutality, acts of terror, and King's negotiations with President Johnson. When victory is achieved at its end, it remains all too real that there's a lot more work to do."I'm not even angry at the white man. I'm angry at the black man. How did we get here today from that? All the black man wants to do today is tear each other apart." - my eavesdropping after the movie

I'm not afraid to say I gave up on this film about half way through. Wilkinson and Roth aside the performances were dull, especially the lead who is one note and a far cry from the real MLK. But the writing is what kills this film, a string of screenwriting cliches and awful dialogue.
How the hell did David Oyelowo not get an Oscar nom for best actor?
A great historic piece on a part of US history during the Civil Rights Movement. Some great acting and great directing. Might see this again.

A languorous look at Dr. King's life and legacy, encapsulated in the events leading up to the march from Selma to Montgomery. There are highlights: David Oyelowo's performance in the lead role, and Stephan James' turn as civil rights icon John Lewis were both moving. Carmen Ejogo also infuses Coretta Scott King with a quiet dignity. But the pace is slow and the call to peaceful resistance feels passive, despite dialogue telling you that just the opposite is true. The message of the film is unassailable, but the vessel - the film itself -- is imperfect.

There were times while I was watching Selma that I forgot it wasn't a documentary. David Oyelowo so completely transforms into Martin Luther King, Jr. that it is easy to forget that fact.I watched this film on Martin Luther King Day, and how better really to honor the great Dr. King's legacy than to be reminded of his incredible legacy through film. Ava DuVernay gives us perhaps the seminal film on the American Civil Rights Movement, and presents us with the additional stories of the other often overlooked players of that historic time. What is most remarkable about Selma is that no screentime goes to waste. Every frame seems weighty and full of import, so much so that the over two hours' runtime is well deserved. With excellent performances all around from a strong cast as well as excellent work behind the camera, Selma is an outstanding entry into the film anthology of American history.
Moving film that often falls short in the telling of such a historic event. Good, but far from great.

This film made me cry at least twice. The depictions of violence were heart wrenching. The filmmakers seemed to intentionally linger on the violent scenes in order to force the viewer to confront the brutality instead of offering a fleeting glimpse of it, which most documentaries tend to do with violent scenes. I read that some people thought the portrayal of LBJ wasn't accurate or fair (but I'm not a historian of this era). I think I enjoyed Stephan James's portrayal of John Lewis the best.

I knew this was going to be a Very Important Movie, but turned out it was also really well-made. I've seen documentaries and footage from Selma but a movie like this has the ability to put you inside the events in a way that documentaries can't. I want everyone to see this.

A good film but a bit underwhelming. The actor chosen to play Dr. King sure resembles him but has the charisma of cardboard nor does he even remotely sound like him. Was there no African-American actors available to play MLK, they had to choose a Brit? They also made the mistake of choosing a director with such little big screen experience. Her last directing experience was an episode of Scandal and it showed. This film lacked the pacing and storytelling it takes for a 2 hour film. The supporting cast was superb which also made the role of MLK seem even smaller in comparison. Good film, but missed the point to expand further on fight for voting rights in Selma.

There's been a lot of talk about the Oscar snubs for Selma. It only got a 'Best Picture' and a 'Best Song' nomination but failed to get nominated in any other category.Now I won't deny that there's a 'soft' kind of racism at play here, combined with an unfortunate release date and a bad Oscar campaign. But did 'Selma' really deserve to be nominated in other categories? Well, let's see.First of all: Selma is a hard watch. It doesn't shy away from showing you the awful truth. I often flinched and felt my stomach turn in disgust while watching the atrocities on screen. So far so good - but in between those poignant moments the movie struggles to hold your attention. And yes, that is largely due to a screenplay that's never more than just 'ok'.Another Oscar snub was for Ava Duvernay, the director, a black female. She would've been the first black female to be nominated for a 'Best Director' statue. But to be quite frank: visually the movie is no '12 Years a Slave'. It's decently directed but nothing ever pops the way it should and again the small moments are never noteworthy.Is 'Selma' an important film? Yes. Why? Because Oscars are political. Period. Therefore it is important for a film with this message to be included in the race. Does it deserve to win or did it deserve to get nominated in other categories? No. Because in spite of its important and powerful message, the film as a whole doesn't have the qualities of an Oscar winner. It's a good film but it fails to be as great as its real life subject.

The long-awaited film adaptation of Martin Luther King Jr.'s exploits focuses on his infamous opposition to the restriction of African American voters and his courageous marches through Selma, Alabama. David Oyelowo is pitch-perfect as King, portraying him as a humbled man who often doubts the implications of his actions, while still delivering the gravitas and speeches the man was known for. The rest of the cast is uniformly excellent with some heavy hitters like Martin Sheen and Cuba Gooding Jr in small roles and plenty of familiar faces in King's entourage. The real weight of the film comes with the striking, unpredictable violence and nowhere is that more apparent than in the opening five minutes which completely took me by surprise. The racial inequality is handled very matter-of-factly and while it is powerful filmmaking it sickens me that this time in mankind's history was only half a decade ago. The directing is stellar, the acting superb, and the story is so well-told that I believe this film should be primary viewing in schools as a great history lesson and eye-opener to respect your fellow man.
A majestic historical drama that lays bare the ugliness of the Jim Crow police state and the courage of those who fought it. Should have been nominated for WAY more than 2 Academy Awards.

Fantastic performances all around and a sure-footed script give new director Ava DuVernay a solid base to showcase her skills. Though the film slips at times, the overall take-away is certainly moving.
If you haven't seen it, get to a theatre! Nothing that I expected! An amazing point of view to history!

Director Ava DuVernay explores the time, place and events with complexity, while David Oyelowo, as King, is mesmerising - inhabiting the role completely. The only jarring note, for me, was a minor one - the rather self-congratulatory end credits and John Legend's bombastic theme. And as some have argued, perhaps the film is not entirely fair to LBJ. But that's another story - on the whole this is a strong, unsentimental take on Selma, with resonance for today.

Another movie about Martin Luther King and his struggle. Nothing stood out about this movie compared to every other movie ever made about the movement or his life. "Mississippi Burning" was a much better movie, and it didn't get the ratings this one did. This was more like watching a documentary than anything.
If you see one film this year, make it "Selma." Seriously. Outstanding performance by David Oyelowo and powerful emotional and historical drama.
Selma [US, 2014] I like how Martin Luther King was portrayed here as a human and not as a god. I am deeply moved. 7.5/10
A fine depiction of MLK's march from Selma to Montgomery, AL. First rate performances all around. Though I didn't quite buy Wilkinson's portrayal of Johnson. Recommended.

Nominated for Best Picture (well-deserved) "Selma" is a look at Dr. King's march on Selma in 1965 and all the turmoil surrounding the civil rights movement in the 1960's as he battles enemies both from outside and within. Acting is excellent all the way around and especially Carmen Ejogo as Coretta Scott King (Cory). She missed out on a best actress nod. Like "American Sniper" should be seen by every American but for a different reason.
A Honest portrayal of Martin Luther King that should not have been snubbed by the Oscars.
A pretty well done retelling of MLK Jr.'s legacy with outstanding performances including Ms. Winfrey.

I wanted to see more organizing of the protests and training of the protesters. I also wanted to get to know the organizers and participants better as people. It's not that I didn't like the glimpses into King's personal life and struggles, but it took away focus from what is presumably the focus of the film: the behind-the-scenes of those protests, and peaceful protests in general. The actors were good, especially King. I wish also that they had used less slow motion. It made the scenes seem more movie-like as opposed to realistic and visceral.

Mi pregunta es que hace que una pelicula como American Sniper tenga 6 nominaciones al Oscar y Selma tenga solo 2. Es inconsebible que no se reconozca la calidad filmica de esta produccion en sus principales categorias. Oyelowo se transformo en Dr. King, lo hizo creible, admirable, se encarno en el personaje. DuVernay como directora es digno de reconocimiento al retratar on delicadeza y sin romanticismo una historia que nos interesa a todos y que motiva a seguir en la lucha.Selma es de lo poco bueno que se produjo en el 2014. Se debe ver.My question is, what makes American Sniper to deserve 6 nominations and Selma only 2. It is inconceivable that the major categories were not recongnized by the academy. Oyelowo nailed the character, he tranformed himself in Dr. King, he was believable. DuVernay deserved a nomination not for being a black womand director but for bringin to life a remarkable and iconic story without cheap hollywood cheap romanticism. Selma is one of the few good films we could see in 2014. A must see.
SELMA embodies the brutal conflicts in the South only 50 years ago.
Easily the best American film this year, and certainly the most important.

David Oyelowo is absolutely amazing, making the Oscar snub that much more unbelievable. Common and John Legend highlight the soundtrack, and the drama is very realistic and more importantly inspiring.

It is a shame David Oyelowo was snubbed by the Academy. This is one of the best pictures of the year. May win an Oscar for best original song, but stiff competition this year will leave Selma off the winner's list for major categories.
The whole time I thought Carmen Ejogo was Sanaa Lathan. An important film but only a tiny glimpse of a much bigger story.

Must see movie! History sure does repeat itself. Touches on issues still relevant today. Switch the word 'black' with 'gay' and it makes you wonder what the name of the movie our grand kids will be watching in theaters that addresses the way we restricted the rights of gay people as recent as 2015.
EXCELLENT MOVIE! GREAT ACTORS, POWERFUL MESSAGE! HAPPY BDAY DR. MARTIN LUTHER KING JR. THANK YOU FOR YOUR WORK AND DEDICATION TO EQUALITY.

Much like Daniel Day-Lewis and Lincoln (2012) three years ago, Selma (2015) is a perfect example of an astounding performance elevating what is otherwise merely a decent film. Whenever the camera is focused on David Oyelowo's Dr. Martin Luther King, the story of Selma has a sharp focus. However, when the camera strays from its lead, the film begins to wander amongst all of the other (mostly-difficult-to-identify) characters. Partially, this is due to focusing on one event in a much longer story, which involved many many people, so it's understandable. Oyelowo's King is a fresh and blood human being - not a marble statue - burdened with doubts and flaws but possessing undeniable talents tailored-made for the U.S. Civil Rights Movement. Quite frankly, it would be an injustice if anyone but Oyelowo won this year's Best Actor Oscar but he isn't nominated, so there you go. Well done, Hollywood

Certainly, not the best film, but the most important film. David Oyelowo has done a role for the ages. Tom Wilkinson and Tim Roth also do one of the best performances of their already-distinguished careers. A little editing could had made it better, but it was beautifully shot and packed an emotional punch. Everyone should see this movie.

Oyelowo gives an impressive showcase performance as MLK. Despite some occasionally nice artistic flourishes and a modern, pop beat, most of the rest of the movie seems small. Almost all key non-black characters in the gov't. are also negatively portrayed making the film too literally black vs white . The actual story was strong enough on its own and should have been left to stand unaltered.

Watched Selma last week with a good friend and here are some thoughts. The movie has some really good acting and well directed scenes, especially those that take place on the infamous bridge where MLK and supporters marched from Selma to Montgomery Alabama. I am surprised the guy that played MLK, David Oyelowo didn't get an Oscar nomination for best actor because he deserved it but the Oscars have sucked recently anyway so who cares right. Anyway, see it for the history but there were a couple slow parts too. Can't win them all!
Fantastic, emotional without being manipulative.
Pretty by-the-numbers bio-pic, good performance by Oyelowo, but a bit dry throughout.
Excellent captivating movie. A "must see" for everyone.

David Oyelowo is resonant as Dr. King. If you have half an eye for performance value, no one can argue that. Performances like these make the movie-goer question precisely why British men have a longer track record than American actors for giving great performances as African American historical figures. However, the big thing is that the film is set in 1965 and strangely feels chillingly contemporary. Selma is a relevant film, moreso now than ever before, as this type of stuff - the fight for equality in the polls as well as equality in general - continues to go on today, both on US soil and overseas. As a presentation of Dr. King, it was absolutely brilliant. It put his flaws and doubts right in the spotlight with his genius. He was the man the world saw 50 years ago, not the man we see in the animated history videos in school. The film was really wordy, but all those words were equally important. The whole thing was almost Shakespearean.The film wasn't the biopic we wanted. The film was the biopic we NEEDED.
Selma is a well-acted and directed 45 minute TV special trapped in a 2 hour movies body. Oyelowo is great as Dr.King, but Selma never goes anywhere. C+

Strong perfomance from Oyelowo lifts this film to a higher level. But the acting from the ensemble is steady, the direction from Duvernay impeccable. Moving and powerful, this film is a refreshing depiction of the events that led to the Selma march, a significant moment in this nation's continual struggle to be true to its core principles.
In telling the dark, twisting reality of our nation, Selma provides hard-to-watch, yet moving scenes filled with truly remarkable performances.

When the art of terrific film making meets an inspiring story, you see the true art of cinema arise. With terrific performances across the board, Selma does what no amount of textbooks, documentaries or teaching can do. You're not simply learning about this story, you're experiencing each crippling blow and every beautifully articulated word.

WOW THAT WAS HARD TO WATCH. The movie starts with a gut punch in the first ~10 minutes and doesn't let up. Watching it was a rollercoaster between horror at the brutalities and seething rage at the continuous little indignities. Even though it ended on a positive note, there was at least one more gutpunch hidden in the "where are they now" end shots. Go see it.

Took my boys to see Selma on MLK Day. Multidimensional storytelling sheds light on the conflicts and challenges to the 60s Civil Rights Movement, and MLK's efforts to to get Voting Rights legislation passed. We get to see MLK's doubts, fears, and personal failures. All of it presented and portrayed in a very sensitive and impressively cinematic fashion. I was fortunate enough to privately meet with Martin's wife Coretta back in the late 80s. It was a thrill I will never forget. This movie reminds me why I'm proud to be American and African-American. Our contribution in this country is so deeply ingrained, both politically and culturally. What would American be like without Rock and Roll, Jazz, or the courage of those brave people in portrayed this movie. This is American history. Love it or leave it.
Great historical drama Riveting

While there are claims the movie is not 100% accurate, I must say few about actual people/events ARE 100% accurate. It depicted Dr. King in a light of being the peace loving, educated, strong civil rights leader and man of god that he was. A bold performance by all. Well worth seeing.
A well-casted, well-rounded evaluation of 1965 that is as relevant as ever.

Selma thrives and flourishes thanks to a star making performance from David Oyelowo, terrific authentic production design and shockingly realistic scenes of police brutality. However, it pains me to say that due to bad pacing and a stretched run time - I felt myself struggle to reach the end of the march. Tim Roth, Wendell Pierce and Tom Wilkinson give impressive supporting turns that keep the film afloat and I was also impressed by the candid take on MLK Jr.'s private life regarding his affairs that has often been swept under the rug regarding his cinematic manifestations. Other problems arise as producer, Oprah, feels she has to act in the film and pops up sporadically as a glorified extra which makes for distracting viewing. Some odd music cues, stale direction and uncertainty to the story it wants to tell; Selma is the most mediocre of the Best Picture nominees this year at the Academy Awards. Nevertheless, if you are not well versed in the history of the civil rights movement, this film could be a nice eye-opener to the plight and struggle of African Americans during the 60's

Just viewed this as part of Odeon's screen unseen and it could be one of the most important films made this year.David Oyelowo is tour de force as Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. in this story of how the Voting Rights Act of 1965 came to pass.It is an excellent and powerful film that depicts the struggles that black people went through to vote, something that we all take for granted and in this day and age don't even bother to use.

A very fine film. I believe it does a good job of allowing us into the "movement" to see the stresses and strains. It de-mythologizes King and makes him more real. Personally I think the film also shows President Johnson to be a man seeking to do good but pulled in so many directions. I think everyone should see this film to remember where we come from and to catch a glimpse of where we need to go.

Complex in its portrayal of King (who is shown as a man with flaws, vices, fears and doubts, not as a saint-figure), Selma is a strong performance surrounded by two hours of melodrama. Yet the melodrama is effective. Careful framing, a powerful score that tugs at all the right heartstrings and some very good performances from the supporting cast elevate Selma from a biographical historical drama to a good movie. And white it's true that some moments are cringeworthy the overall effect is undeniably powerful. Selma is a movie that sucs you into the civil rights struggle and doesn't let go.Timely, well shot and well cast Selma is one biographical drama that stands out from the pack, and a movie definitely worth seeing.

If there has been another film about Martin Luther King then I don't know of it so that makes this essential viewing for those who like to learn a bit through movies. This is as good, but no better than most historical biopics but manages to keep your interest even if you do know how it ends.

Emotionally moving, and it never stops...from the moment when four beautiful little black girls are murdered in a Klan bombing of their church, to the moment when LBJ signs the bill to enact the right to vote for blacks. You viscerally feel the beatings, shootings, and even the spiritual songs. I came away with a new knowledge...of how when this all took place (I was 11 and oblivious to news programs then) it was as if we were at war down south. I had no idea just how brutal that 'war was.
Saw it and didn't really like it. Sorry!

Exceptional. Should have been nominated for Best Actor and Best Director. A fascinating history of the personalities and politics involved with passing the Voting Rights Act. Simply a mesmerizing film.
"When will we be free? Soon and very soon. Because you shall reap what you saw.When will we be free? Soon and very soon. Because no lie can live forever. "Commanding. Bold. Magnificent. Hats off.

This is an important movie - a call to action to anyone who feels like they are being put down systemically, and a deliberate humanizing of a national hero whose gifts and victories become all the more real once you can catch a glimpse of his flaws

Beautiful, because it's a careful and thoughtful exercise in filmmaking. Horrifying, because it is real, it has happened. Moving, because it is history. You are not watching a movie, what you're watching is history.

Profound expose on the power of conviction, transparency, love. Story did a wonderful job of elevating the sensitive, most meaningful questions and empowering the audience to think for themselves about what's right, and realize it is always the right time to do the right thing. Phenomenal acting across the entire cast.

"Selma" 10 Scale Rating: 7.5 (Very Good) ...The Good: David Oyelowo is outstanding as Martin Luther King, Jr and it's a shame that he didn't get a Best Actor nod from the Academy. His mannerisms and delivery were spot on and you can tell that he did a lot of research. His speeches were passionate and amazing to watch as well, which made me feel as if the role was exceptionally important to him. Beyond Oyelowo, there are several minor parts played by big actors with Martin Sheen, Oprah Winfrey, and Cuba Gooding, Jr all with cameos. The film itself is well directed and at times powerful. It focused not only on King's strengths, but also on his weaknesses and faults which was refreshing. A lot of biopics come across as hero worship, but that wasn't the case here. The Bad: The film does slow down considerably at times, and makes the 2:07 run time feel longer. On top of that, the overwhelming majority of the supporting cast fade into the background. They are introduced by name, but then don't have much screen time and most of their names are never used again so you forget who they are. That is what truly prevents the film from being great. The supporting cast are under-utilized and therefore become unmemorable.

Selma, starring David Oyelowo as Dr. King, is a moving film that has a couple flaws just on the technical aspects of the movie. It could have done a little better with the pacing and adding some background music to help set the tone of what was happening. Some of the middle of the moving was slow at times. However, I really liked how the film started and finished. Plus, the marching scenes that happened during the movie were very intense. David Oyelowo has a moving performance has Dr. King and you can really see the weight on his shoulders as the leader of this important movement. I give the movie 4/5.

David Oyelowo was robbed, as he turns in a fantastic performance as Dr. King. The film itself, while definitely worthwhile to watch *ahem* ESPECIALLY if you are in favor of increased scrutiny for voter registration *ahem* as it should show you what the direct result of that would be over time and why the SCOTUS decision in the US was also quite detrimental, parts of this didn't work, film wise. The story's great, in fact I'd say the screenplay deserved a nod -- shame on the Academy. The lighting was often off, with actors faces cast in shadow for no particular reason, and some cuts between different shots of a scene (such as a chapel speech) were more distracting from the performance than emphasizing it. Might just be the first-time director getting the feeling for her craft. I'd personally say this, compared to last year's "12 Years a Slave", has a better script, but just isn't as good a film. Definitely worth checking out, though, for the story it tells and the acting performances

The passage of the Voting Rights Act in 1965 is a triumph that becomes embarrassing when I realized that 1) its passage occurred only 10 years before I was born and 2) that in 2013, five members of the Supreme Court saw fit to determine that institutionalized racism was no longer a factor. Fast forward one year later, and you have Ferguson, MO.Much has been made of the historical accuracy of the depiction of certain players in this movie, not the least of which is President Johnson. Normally, I would forgive such inaccuracies provided that the tone and direction of the story were fulfilling, but the inaccuracy of Johnson's contribution and collaboration with Dr. King leads to a very jarring transformation at the end of the movie when President Johnson seems to unequivocally embrace the immediacy of voting rights legislation out of nowhere.There were times throughout this movie that the movie over-exposits, such as when we are introduced to the SCLC and SNCC. That's a good explanation of who the major players in the Civil Rights Movement are, but it can come across as unnecessary if you know your history. And there are times when it doesn't explain enough. Malcolm X makes a very brief appearance, no longer militant, without explanation, and then is never heard from again (due to his off-screen assassination) and without fanfare. Students of history know that Malcolm's spiritual transformation came about after making his Hajj to Mecca, but the lack of explanation and subsequent disappearance of his character makes his presence in the movie superfluous.More "Glory" than "12 Years a Slave," "Selma" is a good film to have in American classrooms. It is such a shame to not have Dr. King's actual words in the movie, but David Oyelowo does a brilliant job as Dr. King. His lack of Academy Award nomination is a snub of the highest order and is unforgivable in the worlds of acting and history.
Well acted and beautifully shot, this film captures the drama of Luther King's civil rights movement with passionate direction.

SelmaGood acting, uneven directing, a decent script and a quality film score make for a compelling drama. The directing for Selma was pedestrian but not terrible for a first-timer. The camera work offers no surprises nor innovations and there is nothing about the blocking of scenes, whether in churches, on the streets or on the bridge, that enhances the action and drama. The upshot is that Selma is mainly by the books directing but over use of camera gimmickry didn't distract us from the story. It's average and adequate, not terrible, directing. Give credit to the writers and director for showing the flaws and foibles as well as the successes and brilliance of Dr. King in his entirety. No man is perfect, and to portray him as such would have been a discredit to his legacy. Not only are his oft presented infidelities touched upon, but his doubts about his abilities and his leadership mistakes are also part of the film. What makes King and so many leaders in the film remarkable is that they overcame their imperfections to do great things. ?David Oyelowo put in an Oscar worthy performance as Dr. King but failed to get a nomination. His character wasn't mentally or physically challenged, and let's face, not White. Yes, and his name isn't Denzel Washington. But if you play a White man who admits to killing dozens of people, that earns you an Oscar nod. I haven't seen "Sniper", and I am sure Mr. Cooper is great. However, this is an unfortunate slight given the difficulty of playing the historical legend and the quality of the performance. One of my favorite actresses from last year, Tessa Thompson of "Dear White People", plays the firebrand radical Diane Nash. She doesn't get nearly enough screen time for me. However, she probably got the time her character warranted for the story. Actors playing Andrew Young (Andre Holland) and John Lewis (Stephen James) are also excellent. Nigel Thatch in a brief appearance plays Malcolm X perfectly. And the always entertaining Tim Roth plays to his strength of portraying deranged men, this time, Gov. Wallace. One unfortunate choice was putting a rap song at the end of the movie when there are so many period songs or spirituals that would be more appropriate. I assume it was part of the deal to fund the film and get Common on board as one of the actors. "Glory" is a good song, and Legend is a great singer. And if it got the movie produced, fine. It is, however, out of place. As for the controversy about LBJ: Tom Wilkinson does a good job portraying the conflicted president. From what I know about Johnson, the portrait was fair and accurate. Carmen Ejogo played Coretta King with the dignity required, though her role suffered from inattentive writing and wasn't well flushed out. ??Rating: Pay Full Matinee PriceSelma is entertaining though too long in moments. Tighter editing would have helped with the pacing. A bigger budget may have given the director more opportunities to be creative with the shots. The angles, lighting and pacing didn't match the gravity of the story. The dialogue worked well for the time and place of the movie. ?Peace, Tex Shelters

Although Selma is worth seeing for its historical perspective, I found that the directing was weak. While trying to squeeze out every last drop of emotive acting from David Oyelowo, Director Ava DuVernays failed. I found my self losing interest in scenes before their conclusion: like watching a movie in slow motion. I thoroughly enjoyed the performance of Carmen Ejogo who portrayed a very lifelike Coretta King.
What a waste of time. This movie was just another piece of propaganda.

For anyone who's closely studied the Civil Rights movement, this film might just be a must-see considering the comprehensively excellent acting and voice portraying one of the most motivating and inspirational individuals in history, Martin Luther King, Jr.
David Oyelowo was mesmerizing as Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Superb performance, and not the only one.
Has power and grace in spades. A+

Although a good movie, I can see why it was snubbed for the awards this year, it just seems like a big budget movie filmed like it was a low budget flick. Much dialog was missing due to Dr. King's quotes being banned from use in firms because it is considered "intellectual property." People are reviewing this well because of guilt and because they want to seem like they are post racial, when in reality I am still looking for a movie that truly encapsulates the civil rights movement.
solid film, could have done without Oprah and lot of long winded speeches...

A very good, very powerful, very moving, and very well done film about a very important event. I don't think LBJ had to be such a strong antagonist though, and some of the other minor adversary plots were imperfectly executed/didn't add much to the story, but overall, this film was very well executed.
This was an excellent movie. The producers and cast did a great job. A must see for young adults.

3 out of 5 stars. An earnest and noble portrait of Dr. King, with a terrific performance by David Oyelowo, but the film has technical errors that keep it from being as great as it wants to be. As with many other biopics of people this year, specifically Stephen Hawking in "Theory of Everything," and Alan Turing in "The Imitation Game," "Selma" also wants to not offend anyone with its selective biographical memory. All three films seem to deify their subjects, which keeps them from seeming human, ignoring flaws or unlikeable character traits, which could mar the films' intent. "Selma" is well written, selecting a 2 month period in King's life, instead of trying to incorporate all his accomplishments, which would need an 8 hour canvas at least. While the film is interesting and well acted, it's unwavering tone of "historic importance" sometimes drags and is less entertainment than historic document that wants to be a school staple for future generations to examine as good for them. King's infidelity is only hinted at for example, in an otherwise hermetically sealed portrait of harmonious marriage. What is more troublesome is the cinematography and editing, which continually jump "the line," and seem low budget, almost amateurish. It's unfortunate, because so much of the film is really well done, especially the acting. "Selma" is as polemical by omission as "American Sniper," but the technical work is far less accomplished.

Built and centered on an admirable topic, Selma proves to be a surprisingly weighty historical drama in a season of underwhelming Oscar bait hopefuls. I actually always wondered what a well-made film about Martin Luther King, Jr. would look like that was NOT about the march on Washington, the Montgomery bus boycott, or his assassination. In addition to a different setting than we are used to seeing him in, we also are allowed to look at King the human being, i.e. the flawed man who used politics and arm-twisting in order to achieve his goals. The script avoids pandering hagiography in a similar manner to Lincoln. King understood, both here and in reality, that any struggle would have to be public and caught on camera for Middle America to see, and this helped steer his choice toward demonstrating in Selma, Alabama where resistance would be fierce. We also have David Oyelowo giving an underplayed King, while displaying more assertiveness than we are used to seeing. Oyelowo probably gives the best depiction of MLK we have seen to date and I must join the chorus of voices arguing that this actor was robbed by the Academy for a nomination. There are some problems with accuracy regarding the role of President Johnson, which some historians have rightfully pointed out. Namely, this version of LBJ comes off as a bit cowardly and downright obstructionist toward civil rights. He is shown yelling at King in most of his scenes, conspiring with J. Edgar Hoover to damage King's marriage by releasing evidence of his infidelities to his wife, and only pushing the Voting Rights Act to protect his legacy after it becomes clear the way the wind is blowing. I got news for ya. Johnson, like most if not all U.S. Presidents, probably hated J. Edgar and often avoided him if he could. The wiretapping of King and other Civil Rights leaders predated LBJ, and Hoover often acted unilaterally on that kind of behavior and without oversight. Furthermore, Johnson for the most part approved of King's actions, and specifically in Selma. This is not to say Johnson was an angel. He could be a gigantic asshole. But he was not a coward and he certainly didn't act to obstruct MLK, even if they disagreed on many issues. On that note, they definitely got George Wallace right. He really was a creepy, racist self-absorbed douche - largely unconcerned with the future or his legacy...until he got shot and paralyzed years later.But I digress. This is the kind of low-key, unpretentious, honest story telling I wish I saw more of. The stellar portrayal for our protagonist, competent direction, tight writing, and simple but relevant message make this a must see. Get chill bumps listening to the speeches. Cringe every time nightsticks are brandished and George Wallace opens his mouth. Easily one the best films of the year.

This film should be required viewing in high schools...especially in the south. It's rather unfortunate that many people will choose not to watch this film in its theatrical run due to burnout from the Ferguson riots. Of course, this film was in production before the Ferguson riots even occurred. Both this film and Ferguson should be a reminder that racial tensions and hatred are still alive and well in America. For example, although news coverage of this was sparse, last year the Supreme Court gutted the Voting Rights Act which protected minorities and almost immediately....states (mainly in the south) passed laws to make it harder for minorities to vote. Keep that in mind when you watch this film.

In its lugubrious, methodical way, "Selma" illustrates the issues at play regarding civil rights for black Americans in the 1960s, the options available to Dr. King as the leader of the nonviolent movement, and what he went through in choosing from among those options. Oyelowo's performance as the civil rights leader isn't showy -- it's a solid, heartfelt interpretation that helps give the film its moral center.

Purely amazing, Selma manages to humanize an American historical icon, but at the same time communicate the importance of what he, and so many others stood for. A truly well done film, with superb acting, makes this a must see.

What is there to be said. Selma is an excellent dramatization of the 1965 Voting Rights crisis in the Jim Crow South. The performance and chemistry by and between Oyelowo and Ejogo, MLK and Coretta Scott King, respectively, works well to capture both the public and private lives of the civil rights leaders during this period. I highly recommend seeing this.

It is that time of year when I go see all the Oscar-nominated films I haven't yet seen. Selma was one of those I wanted to see, but was turned off by the talk of the historical inaccuracies when it came to LBJ's portrayal. Combined with the ridiculous Al Sharpton protests because of the lack of Director and Actor nods for anyone in Selma, I wasn't entirely excited about seeing the film. However, I'm a relatively objective person though, so I'm happy to say that, while I haven't seen all of the movies yet for which actors have been nominated, I have to admit that I am stunned about the lack of a nod for David Oyelowo. His performance is outstanding. I'm all for Michael Keaton winning an Oscar, but admittedly, David's performance is right up there. His portrayal as Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. has to be a Top 5 performance. If it truly isn't, then the ones who were nominated must be insanely good. While I cannot speak for the historical accuracy of LBJ's portrayal, I thought the movie treated the history I DO know, very fairly. Selma has some odd moments, such as the sudden introduction, then little-discussed disappearance, of Malcolm X, but there wasn't an over-dramatic over-portrayal of either side. I am from the deep South and saw the ridiculous behavior of white America not too far after that matched pretty well with the whites displayed in Selma. Even after 50 years, the message of Selma remains so strong, not for just black America, but for every race, culture, sexual preference, etc. It seems so ridiculous that we still struggle as a nation to admit that we have pockets of inequality. Women in the work force, continued racism and the absurd stance that some still have about gay marriage. Movies like this should be required watching.

There is a scene of such astonishing power very early on in the movie "Selma," where Martin Luther King calls up Mahalia Jackson in the middle of the night. He is about to go to Selma, Alabama to lead the famous march to Montgomery. He knows the road ahead is dangerous. His life is in danger. J. Edgar Hoover and the FBI have his house watched and his phones tapped. Death threats come in on a regular basis (his wife, Coretta, says at one point that she feels death hanging over her "like a fog"). And history is on the line with the fight for passage of the Voting Rights Act. King tells his friend that he "needs to hear the voice of the Lord." Jackson, still in her nightgown, sits on the edge of her bed and sings him a gospel song over the phone. It's a beautiful, haunting moment, deep and true, and yet, we don't see this as King's Agony in the Garden: he is not reduced to the over-simplified image of a Christ figure. "Selma" is far too serious (I know the word is loaded) for such facile reductions of character. King is a leader, an activist. He makes difficult choices. He is tactful about how he uses his followers to influence political power. This is history made alive. The movie never feels stagnant or dull or too much like a school lesson; it never crosses into that absurd realm of syrupy inspiration that is characteristic of so many other "serious" historical dramas. It is electric, even thrilling. I am amazed to find out that the director, Ava DuVernay was not nominated for an Oscar for Best Director. It's an appalling snub. This is one of the year's best movies, and it deserves to be seen, recognized, and absorbed. In the context of Ferguson and the national dialogue about racial injustice, this movie comes along at an important point in time. If it doesn't break the box office or win Best Picture, I think it will still take its place in movie history.

Selma arrives at a time where racial politics have reentered the American landscape and seems to have reignited creative fires in recent projects ranging from the Butler, Django Unchained, Lincoln and last years Best Picture winner 12 Years a Slave. In the case of Selma, it had been gestating for a while with Lee Butler attached to direct, which probably was what brought Oprah's attention to the project along with Brad Pitt's Plan B Entertainment to fast track production on this little gem which it truely is, not a major studio film even though Paramount distributes it, but a Pathe UK production. Despite all the grumbling over the lack of nominations for the 2015 Oscars with the exception of song and pic, the main thing film critics and fans should be focusing on is the arrival of David Oleyowo as Martin Luthor King Jr, who has mastered the now iconic speechifying voice and tambre, but also brings a humanity and doubt to the character to help make him a human and relatable character for the younger generation and helps you to get to know what he may have be like in the midst against the giant that is US politics and the Civil War. Having only seen him in a few supporting roles, notably the Rise of the Planet of the Apes, I am excited to see what the King Role will bring him. The rest of the cast is strong, including the ever reliable Roth and Wilkenson in key roles. But as a film, its strictly servicable compared to the aforementioned films and just acts as a study for that particular moment in US history and best viewed as a character study if anything else. In a less competitive year, David would most likely have received a Best Actor nomination for his work which is the nomination the pic should have received imho. Above average.

Undoubtedly powerful and unflinchingly portrayed, this is the story of MLK's journey from Selma to Birmingham in an effort to truly gain the right to vote for African Americans. Delving deeper into MLK, we find that he was a very flawed man, and it is to be applauded that director Ava DuVernay did not make this a flowery love letter to MLK and followers alike. Incredible performances from Wilkinson as President Johnson and Roth as bull-headed politician Wallace, really anchor the story, but David Oyelowo delivers a one-of-a-kind performance as MLK. This unclouded depiction of 60s life in the South, (mainly Alabama in the film), shows us how far we have come and more so, how much further we have left to go. Rated 3.75 out of 5. 3.5/4.0There is no denying that "Selma" is an incredibly powerful and emotionally moving piece of work. The movie tells the story of the 1965 Selma to Montgomery voting rights marches led by Martin Luther King, Jr. The key reason why the movie works is David Oyelowo who portrays King in his first major leading film role. He succeeds in portraying the immense power and (more importantly) heart of this great man. While justifiably glorifying King, the movie never attempts to portray him as a flawless man as evident from the nuances of his family life and relationship with his wife Coretta (well played by Carmen Ejogo). While far less graphic, "Selma" is in my opinion more powerful in depicting racial oppression than last year's Oscar winner "12 Years a Slave". Kudos to little known female director Ava DuVernay ("Middle of Nowhere") who manages to infuse the right amount of style (including some slo-mo shots) to give integral scenes the right amount of dramatic punch.The movie's sole flaw (that one forgives given its emotional strength) is that a lot of the key supporting characters particularly those who played a key part in the real-life march are underdeveloped and uninteresting including James Bevel (rap star Common who collaborates with the great John Legend on the moving theme song for the film "Glory"), Hosea Williams (Wendell Pierce), Amelia Boynton Robinson (Lorraine Toussaint) and SNCC's John Lewis (Stephan James). However, that is forgivable by smaller less significant roles including Oprah Winfrey (also produces) as Annie Lee Cooper who has only two key scenes including one where she tries to unsuccessfully vote and a sequence involving the death of teenager Jimmi Lee Jackson by the police. The ensuing sequence with King at the morgue with his nearly blind grandfather (Henry G. Sanders) that is followed by a speech by King at the boy's funeral alone make the film well worth seeing. One of the most difficult things to reenact on film are historic speeches especially if by a character as prolific as King and "Selma" is great (again thanks to Oyelowo) for depicting the grandeur of these moments - they feel real! Tom Wilkinson is good portraying President Johnson who had a somewhat of a love-hate relationship with King (the character's depiction in the film has drawn some controversy), Giovanni Ribisi as his advisor Lee C. White and Tim Roth as racist Alabama governor George Wallace. Nominated for 2 Oscars: Picture, Original Song. (It is an atrocity that the movie didn't get more nominations particularly one for Oyelowo).
Topical, powerful, necessary.

I can see why SELMA has been nominated BEST PICTURE this year. It is a story still relevant to our times... one that does indeed shows how far we have come as a nation but yet how far we still have to go. In so many aspects, we face the same turmoils of racism and inequality as we did decades ago with the Civil Rights Movement. Don't be fooled people, the movement is still happening everyday in our news! SELMA demonstrates this without ever truly being preachy, as a lot of political biopics do. Did I love the film? No. Is it something I will truly remember in a few years even, most likely not... However, it is very much worth seeing and holds a lot of power. The film raises above typical historical films by showing the different perspectives at hand and often introducing a myriad of characters that come and go quickly but leave their mark, revealing their purpose in the end. You always know who the hero is in the end, after all it is a three-month story on Martin Luther King Jr... Yet, you see the good side and bad side and convergence of both when political powers are used for the better... The film starts with a bang that dropped my jaw to the floor and from there had some terrific moments... brutal and cringe-worthy at times... to so small and silent that expression itself tells every word necessary. Is it great direction? No. I know a lot of people are saying the director was snubbed for an Oscar nomination, however I honestly feel that there are a lot of directors out there that could have made the same film once having such script, talent and budget in hand... There is not a stand-out style of direction here that is truly recognizable or "new", for me at least... Are performance s overlooked? Definitely. David Oyelowo does indeed deserve a Best Actor Nomination but was sadly overlooked. As Oprah, who produced and has a supporting role in the film, has said interviews, this is, as she hopes, a film that will be required viewings in school one day. I can agree to that. The film has a lot to say without being tedious... Something another recent, critically-acclaimed bio-pic, LINCOLN really failed to do. Seriously, do not even get me started on the snooze-fest called LINCOLN!!! As more films are made of past historical figures, may they please go along the venture of SELMA...
Definitely see this one in a theater, it would probably suck as far as experiences on the small screen.

The image we're greeted with at the onset of Selma, staring directly at us, is the face of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. But this is not the Dr. King we know from the sound bites and TV footage that immortalized him as a mighty orator with a famous dream. This Dr. King looks uncomfortable, restless and out of his element as he rehearses his Noble Peace Prize acceptance speech in the privacy of his hotel suite.The Dr. King he himself sees in the mirror is unfamiliar to him as well; All dressed up to accept an award for peace when he knows how much violence and struggle is yet to be endured in his campaign for civil rights. Just as he gazes at his reflection, contemplating how far he's come and how far he's still to go, so too does Selma hold a mirror up to modern America and ask its people to consider the same questions.Director Ava DuVernay (working from her largely rewritten draft of an original script by Paul Webb) has no intention of taking the easy way around the story of the protest marches King led from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama, or of dampering its echoes in the troubled racial politics of today. Though set in the summer of '65, it is a film very much about the here and now, told with a verve and vitality that historical docudramas often lack.Rather than cut and paste every highlight from the pages of some textbook, DuVernay focusses solely on one single mission out of the dozens that King (David Oyelowo) took up in his 13 years of political activism: The right for black citizens to vote in the state of Alabama.With tensions between the African American community and the Jim Crow South already at a fever pitch following the Civil Rights Act, King appeals to Lyndon B. Johnson (Tom Wilkinson) for immediate voting reform legislation, but the harried president - understandably preoccupied with a costly war in Vietnam - considers it a lower priority.This controversial depiction of Johnson has already sparked some dissent from LBJ supporters who resent that he comes off as anything less than saintly. However, Wilkinson's fine performance makes it clear that he's not the bad guy, but a shrewd pragmatist caught between a rock and a hard place, unwilling and unable to budge until one of those two sides does so first.Perhaps those LBJ complaints would bear more weight if DuVernay hadn't applied the same scrutinizing humanism to King as well, who is by no means deified in this picture. DuVernay and Oyelowo are more interested in showing that even the greatest of men are as flawed as the rest of us.Yes, King is a loving husband and father, but also an imperfect one. DuVernay evokes the marital rifts between him and his wife Coretta Scott-King (Carmen Ejogo) by editing their exchanges as a visual back-and-forth without showing both their faces together in the same shot.Yes, King is a charismatic leader, but at times is doubtful about his own cause. As effective as Oyelowo is at channeling the hair-raising timber and cadence of King's voice, he's even more impressive when grappling silently with the human cost of his crusade.It's easy for movies to play the old 'a-noble-cause-is-worth-dying-for' card, but this one truly and thoroughly explores that dilemma. One of Oyelowo's most affecting moments comes when King, locked in the Selma county jail, waxes philosophic to his fellow activist Ralph Abernathy: "A man stands up only to be struck down. And what of the people who followed him?"But Selma never feels preachy - even when the reverend Dr. King is literally sermonizing - because the film is as much about the practicalities and politicking behind the Selma marches as it is about the ideologies that inspired them. The manipulation and tactics employed by all camps are portrayed, from blackmail to backroom negotiations to television exposure. In some ways it's reminiscent of Steven Spielberg's Lincoln, but nowhere near as reserved in its stylistic execution.DuVernay's direction is never less than gripping, using beautifully composed images and carefully selected music to make some striking juxtapositions. The brutal assault of protestors on the Edmund Pettus Bridge (the day that would be known as Bloody Sunday), for instance, is underscored by Martha Bass' rendition of "Walk With Me" to add ironic sting.And rising cinematography star Bradford Young uses low angles to communicate power and moral standing in dynamic ways; Close-ups of bigoted Alabama governor George Wallace (Tim Roth) are framed differently than close-ups of King for a reason.Because all this care has been taken to keep us engaged throughout, by the time the film reaches its epic finale on the steps of the State Capitol in Montgomery, it's every bit as stirring as it aims to be despite being a predictable dramatic beat. And it's here where the parallels between past and present become pointedly clear, as sung in the truthful lyrics of the end credit single "Glory" (by John Legend and rap artist Common):One son died, his spirit is revisitin' usTruant livin' livin' in us, resistance is usThat's why Rosa sat on the busThat's why we walk through Ferguson with our hands upWhen it go down we woman and man upThey say, "Stay down" and we stand upShots, we on the ground, the camera panned upKing pointed to the mountain top and we ran upSelma is so much more than an engrossing history lesson on film. Selma is a rallying cry for a movement that must keep marching, and a glorious rallying cry at that. Selma is now.
Selma was the most emotionally affecting film I've seen in the past few months-so moving.

Selma is a great depiction of Martin Luther King in the days when he wanted black people to vote. Ava DuVernay confidently directs it with a stunning and beautiful portrayal of Dr. Martin Luther King by David Oyelowo. The film also has one of the best cinematographies of the year, and one of the best original songs in "Glory".
I thought David Oyelowo did a good job playing Martin Luther King, Jr. He nailed that accent. The film overall is average. It's a boring story. There is nothing exciting about this movie.
David Oyelowo does a Outstanding performance that elevates this film to being great, Selma is a powerful film on the civil rights that brings up emotion and at times the horror of the American past.

Okay, I am a 3 star guy, Love the movie almost as much as I love the historic overview of an amazing place and time. Gripping real world looks inside looks of a place and time that can only be described as horrible. Director DuVernay nails it and should have been included in the list of nomination for Oscar consideration. The cinematographic excellence rival any other movie I seen this year. Acting, top to bottom, was outstanding as well. for me... personally... the lead actor David Oyelowo is where the fifth star falls off my rating. Having my sense filled with the real MLK, Jr. does not help him. In fact there is no one on the big screen who can reach that powerful and lasting presence and thus, he fail short as well. Lot's of upset people out there concerning his snub for the Oscar, to me he did an already job but not Oscar worthy job. I do look forward to other Oyelowo attempts in the future, I am sure they will be great.

This movie was thrilling and satisfying. I was/am grateful for this film. It definitely deserves so many more awards than it has received thus far. The adaption of MLK Jr. portrayed by D. Oyelowo is riveting and if you close your eyes, you would never know that it's NOT the real MLK. Kudo's to Ms. Ava on her directing and cast choices. Here Here!!!

There is a lot to recommend this movie, and a few things not so much. The performances are very good, albeit in my opinion and maybe some of the other Old Geezers Who Go To The Matinee Alone, a bit wooden and stereotypic at times. The evil southern racists are stamped out of one model and the noble civil rights workers are also one dimensional. Having said that I'd still say go because the highs are a lot higher than the lows are low. There has been a lot written about the way Lyndon Johnson, masterfully played by Tom Wilkinson, is portrayed as ambivalent or even hostile to Dr. Martin Luther King's goals for the Selma march. That is simply ahistorical and got on my nerves until the end where Johnson seemed to have some sort of 'road to Damascus' moment. The action is pretty good but the movie lags at times. All in all I was impressed and recommend it although at 2+ hours you'll need your depends. . .or is that just me?
Interesting historical perspective and well done, but would not characterize it as outstanding.
OK movie. Definitely NOT Academy Award material...
I love it! It renewed my sense of awe and respect for Martin Luther King Jr. and all of those who shaped the civil rights movement.

Very good film with some excellent acting. Always loved King's speeches and the best lines in the movie were written originally by him. The saddest thing however was that I left the theater with a bad taste in my mouth. As the credit roll, a rap song plays talking about marching on Ferguson with hands up. Since the poor kid in Ferguson didn't have his hands up but was attacking the cop, apparently we have gone from defending the truth to defending a lie. Giving his teaching on the dangers of violence, Dr. King must be looking down from heaven weeping.
It is haunting, when I look at our past and how it is not recognized by our present youth who hold the key to our future.

It comes with a heavy heart to say, this is not the be all and end all for films. Selma tries it's best to capture the raw essence of the racially motivated events at hand yet it ultimately does not live up to the task, creating at times a drawn out, slowly paced biopic that, at it's greatest fault, crafts Dr. King not as a man, but as a god. The cast does terrific jobs and the directing is to be praised beyond a doubt, as well this is an important film to be seen purely based on it's relevance and message, as well as to better understand the strides and faults we as a nation have made over the decades, however as a film, I begrudgingly say, I am not surprised at the amounts of snubs Selma received from the Academy earlier this day. Selma attempts to reach greatness, and nearly reaches it, but sadly falls just short.

Powerful, emotional, righteous, and masterfully realized, Selma is a film brimming with life and passion! These men and women took up this righteous cause and let no one deter them. This movie is nothing less than a historical document that palpably finds the mood and atmosphere of the civil rights movement. It certainly helps that David Oyelowo completely commits and nails his MILK performance, humanizing him with deep troubles, passions, and immense courage. This is a movie that MUST be seen by an race, color, creed, or gender. I was in awe and at it's mercy the whole time.

Impeccably directed by Ava DuVernay with an autobiographical performance by David Oyelowo, Selma, stands tall as one of the year's best films and showcases how the struggles of our past remain ever present.
Powerful story of Dr King and the Civil Rights act.

Can I give this movie more than 5 stars? Fantastic, wonderful, epic, the words just cannot do this film justice. Go see it, everyone. If you can watch this movie without being moved then you have no heart. Even though I am well acquainted with history, watching it played out in this film brought me to tears many times over.
Inspired including the music. You have to hold back the tears.
VERY EMOTIONAL AND DIFFICULT BUT IMPORTANT REMINDER OF HOW FAR WE'VE COME AND HOW FAR WE STILL HAVE TO GO

The acting is phenomenal, but overall it's way too straightforward for the message it's trying to send. The cinematography was unique and made it better, but overall it lacks a spark to truly make it remarkable, which any movie about MLK should be/have.
My Favorite Film Is 1941's Citizen Kane.

Een krachtig waargebeurd drama over het leven van Martin Luther King wordt gedragen door een powerhouse prestatie van David Oyelowo. Het is een moeilijk film om na te kijken, vooral omdat de realiteit zo verschrikkelijk is om te accepteren. Het is ook de reden waarom we na dit soort films kijken, en Selma doet dat als geen beste. Verplichte kost voor geschiedenislessen zou deze film moeten zijn !

Selma was a fantastic film. I thought the portrayal of LBJ was accurate of a politician trying to balance a enormous amount of policies that a president has to consider on one plate. Another well represented aspect of the film was MLK himself. We all know MLK the ideal. The ideal of non-violent yet disruptive protests that many protests today try to resemble to bring awareness to issues in our society. But what you see in this film is the man. MLK laughing and enjoying a meal with his friends. MLK working on martial issues and the struggle inside himself of understanding his lasting legacy and how history would perceive him with every action he did. How David Oyelowo did not get a best actor nomination from the Academy is a travesty. This is one of the best pictures of 2014 and certainly one many people should see.

Doctor Martin Luther King is rightfully one of the most prominent and revered historical figures of the twentieth century. He worked tirelessly to give his people- and all Americans- equal rights and dignity, without resorting to violence, hate or extremism, but instead through the power of words, ideals, and nonviolent resistance. So it is fitting that his life has been the subject of many film and television biopics, many of them quite good. And Selma may be the best yet. David Oyelowo was the perfect choice to play Dr. King. Beyond his strong physical resemblance, his speech and mannerisms are almost uncannily like those of the late reverend. He exudes inner strength and determination, and there's just this presence about him when he stands and raises his voice in defiance or exhortation. In scenes where he deliver some of MLK's more famous speeches it's almost like King himself were speaking directly to the audience. In terms of power and authenticity it would not be amiss to compare his performance to that of Daniel Day Lewis in Lincoln.Another similarity with Spielberg's recent biopic is that as much as Selma venerates its subject, it takes every opportunity to humanize him, going beyond the legend we know to show us Martin Luther King the man. He is a great man, a righteous man, but still a man, with fears, doubts, and emotions. He gets frustrated, even angry, and not just at white racists. He longs to be with his wife and children, but too often advancing the cause means life on the road. And like any other man he knows how to cut loose and have some fun with friends. Perhaps more than in any previous portrayal, we get to know Doctor King as a relatable and eve imperfect human being, which makes his accomplishments all the more impressive. Just as it avoids making its protagonist an unknowable icon, Selma avoids the temptation to reduce his opponents into one dimensional caricatures. Make no mistake, the movie makes no attempt to soften the segregationists and race baiters. There are plenty of scenes of snarling troopers beating protestors bloody- or worse. But neither does it reduce them all to ignorant hicks. George Wallace, the grand bigot himself, is calculating and articulate, and far more dangerous for it.Given this nuance, it is all the more baffling that the filmmakers have managed to so badly mischaracterize President Johnson. It's true that LBJ didn't always place the same urgency on civil rights efforts that King did, and that they disagreed on a number of issues such as Vietnam. It is also certainly true that FBI director Hoover was obsessed with discrediting King and used the FBI to monitor and harass him. However to portray Johnson as adversarial towards King or involving himself in Hoover's schemes is at best highly inaccurate and at worst disingenuous. Given LBJ's prominence in the film and the importance given to his interactions with Doctor King, this strikes a very sour note in an otherwise excellent production.Despite this weakness, Selma remains an outstanding film. A nuanced screenplay, strong direction, and high production values take it well beyond the level of the average biographical film, and exceptional acting together with stirring musical choices give it a power worthy of its story. Selma is a moving portrait of a truly great man and a powerful and timely reminder of what he went through so we can be where we are today.

Selma is at times a biopic showing the sequence of events that made one man validate himself as a true champion of non-violent peace causes, and also a political drama about the people and circumstances that played out behind the scenes to create a monumental phenomenon in the national history of a country. The film is epic in scale just due to eh act that it tackles such a grand event; and secondly because of its exceptional handling of the drama that unfolded along the many lines of this fight - the personal front, the family front and the public front.
A Masterpiece film that has me speechless about American history. Strong performance by David Oyelowo as Dr. Martin Luther King,Jr.

Preachy, historically inaccurate, over-dramatized and slooooow... however there was good acting by the two leads. I found the direction to be uneven and some characters stories not brought out enough. This movie could have been much better. There was more to tell. The movie did a very good job of making it feel like I was seeing the 1960's south. I went through the south as a kid and the sets were very well done. I like seeing historic films and pointing out the inaccuracies. The biggest one here is the treatment of President Johnson who was made into a racist. To big of an inaccuracy to forgive for me.

This is a very good film that is propelled by an outstanding performance by David Oyelowo as Martin Luther King Jr. The story is gripping and the directing is masterful from first time feature film director Ava DuVernay. The monologues and even the smaller moments when he is on screen are so well directed and they really deliver that punch that you want them to. The first film in some time that made me tear up from its extremely powerful and shocking opening scene. The film is also not a from birth till death biopic of MLK's life which is often a trap for a film like this it just takes one significant event and focuses in on that and I thought that was a great choice that really worked. Another trap for a biopic like this that I thought was a great aspect and a good choice for this film is it is not a glossy look at the history it is a real look at not only the historical figure we know Dr. King to be but also the man he was. The movie is also masterfully edited with a just over two hour run time. Some of the problems that I personally had with the film is that at times it has its pacing issues and as a result felt like the story was moving at a crawl. Another problem with the film is the fact that Dr. King was the only interesting character in the whole film and when he was not on screen you did not care much. This is the first feature film biopic look at this Martin Luther King Jr and I am sure with this ones success that this will usher in more but this one has set the bar high. 4/5

Biopics have a tendency to play like highlights reels. 'Selma' opens with a refreshing line. As Martin Luther King is being honored with the Nobel Peace Prize, the presenter says something like, "Dr. King, we've heard your dream." By moving immediately past King's most famous moment, the audience is presented with the uncommon opportunity to explore the messy mechanics of the Civil Rights Movement. King is an imperfect man and leader, learning as he goes, who is faced with a challenge of such magnitude that his strategies are never self evident.A choppy script is masked by brilliantly intense performances all around. In particular, David Oyelowo as King, Tom Wilkinson as Lyndon Johnson, and Stephan James as a young John Lewis command every second they are on screen.A side note: For the second year in a row, I'm struck by irony of British actors staging quintessential moments in American history. Last year's '12 Years a Slave' primarily starred British actors as Americans. In this one, King, his wife, LBJ, and George Wallace are all played (very effectively) by Brits. A curious connection between the two movies - Brad Pitt is executive producer. Coincidence? Or is Pitt suggesting that Americans aren't willing to face our own history?

Selma is a flawed but excellent movie. David Oyelowo should definitely be nominated best actor for his performance as Martin Luther King, Jr. When the film ends you can get enough of watching David's performance. Oprah Winfrey didn't chew up the movie this time with her over dramatizations like she did in The Butler which was a thankful surprise to me. The storyline was part excellent and part flawed. On the one hand you have the strained relationship between King and his wife Coretta which was some of the most powerful scenes in the movie as it shines light inside the King family. The part the movie got wrong and is getting criticized about rightly so is the discourse with Lyndon Baines Johnson. Too much of the movie was about the fictitious back and forth between King and LBJ and not enough about the real antagonists Gov. George Wallace and FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover who tried to ruin King's marriage to Coretta. Another aspect of the movie was the PG nature of the violence which was much worse than depicted in the movie. All in all its a very good film that wastes too much time off the march and Martin Luther King and too much time on the fictitious rivalry with LBJ. We still have not had a definitive movie on Martin Luther King, Jr. from Montgomery to Memphis and I think we still need one moving forward. I wouldn't mind a three hour biopic with David Oyelowo back in the lead role and I am sure the audience wouldn't mind either. ficent performance.
