This film is powerful and emotional and David Oyelowo's performance is masterful.
A very accurate and well done piece on a very dark time in America's history. It felt very true without trying to push a message. Great acting. Very well directed.
What a great movie, acting and tory. I can't remember the last time i cried while watching a movie. I did cry towards the end of Selma

I had ridiculously high expectations going into this movie so I was prepared to be at least a little disappointed. IT DID NOT DISAPPOINT IN THE LEAST! It's tore me in half and uplifted me at the same time. This is hands down the best picture of the year. If the Academy Awards don't recognize this then it will be proof positive that those award ceremonies are just popularity contests with an excuse to see rich people in fancy clothes; with not even a tertiary relationship to rewarding cinematic achievement, because this is it. I especially recommend this movie to religious people. This is a Hollywood movie but it does NOT shy away from MLK's relationship with God AT ALL. There is something so transcendent about the scenes where Martin Luther King draws strength from the Holy Spirit and calls on Him for help. Forget any of the controversy you have heard or read and see this movie!I hope this movie will rouse people to positive action in their lives. I cannot praise this movie enough.
It took awhile to get going but once it did it's at times ugly yet powerful.

What I got to say about "Selma" is a good movie of determination and peace. "It's timeless, astonishing, and original." The performances by the hole cast is really good. "David Oyelowo gives one gripping performance...Very remarkable!" The directing by Ava DuVernay is very well directed. The screenplay by Paul Webb is great. The cinematography, score, and effects are good. "I'm raving that "Selma" is a movie that draws inspiration and dramatic of an American masterpiece of a movie."

Really well done, and very moving. I was not even 1 year old when this event happened. It's hard to believe there are so many similarities to politics and bigotry today. Nothing today is as blatant as what happened back then, but the bigotry still echoes through what is happening today.

Paul Webb was bold enough to write this story of one of the greatest human rights leaders in the history of the world. He wrote a strong compelling, and completely real representation of the events surrounding Selma.Ava DuVernay had the audacity to direct and put this story on the big screen. She nailed it perfectly. She captured the emotion of the man, his followers, and everyone involved, including those against him. The cast also nailed every single part, every emotion, and every beat.Selma' is a good movie about a great human being. I'll admit I didn't know much about the actual events, so the movie was quite interesting. The movie focuses on a pivotal moment during the Civil Rights Movement, which focuses on Martin Luther King Jr. trying to march through Selma to Montgomery. Selma is told with with a solid amount of emotion, the events the movie portrays really gets your blood boiling because of how arrogant and hateful people could be back then. This is a powerful movie about a powerful individual who united thousands of people for one great cause and the movie itself truly captures the spirit of Dr King very well. The acting is of course phenomenal, some of the best of the year, especially when you hear David O's natural voice! But what really held 'Selma' back was the whole LBJ storyline and how they made him out as more of a bad buy more than anything else. After the movie I went and read about the events and a lot of other people out there agree (or were upset) about how the directed made him look. He was actually the one who gave MLK the idea to go to Selma and protest there, not Dr King. He also was a very strong supporter of the Civil Rights Movement and was constantly (but secretly) working on solving the situation on a legislative level. So if you are looking for a more factual movie about the events that took place, look for a documentary rather than this. Don't get me wrong, this is an eye opening movie, but it does have it's weaknesses, particularly the portrayal of LBJ and Dr King's personal life storyline, which is quite brief and doesn't really add much to the story. Outside of those complaints, the movie sends a very strong message and a great one at that. Is this movie the Best Picture of the year? No, it's a good movie with a heart at the center of the story, but it lacks to energy and gut punching ability that '12 Years a Slave' had last year to make it truly something special.
A very impressive and important film. David Oyelowo is fantastic.

After all the great reviews I was expecting a moving tale of the march from Selma to Montgomery. That is not what I got. The movie started out well...actually a masterful piece of insight and direction for the first scene. After that it went down hill. The actors playing Johnson and Wallace were ill suited for the role. The actor playing Dr. Martin Luther King, JR lacked the charisma of Dr. King. I remember Dr. King's speeches...I watched the events unfold. This movie did not do justice to either. It would have been better if the story would have been told from the point of view of a participant instead of the leader. And it would have been a hell of a lot better if Oprah Winfrey hadn't hogged scenes, bringing nothing to the story.

A powerful film about the Civil Rights movement. The film goes over one of the events that took place in Selma, Alabama. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. (David Oyelowo doing a FANTASTIC job) leads protestor to non-violent protesting and marching in the wake of trying to get African Americans the right to vote without Jim Crowe Laws. The movie goes over the struggles they must overcome from MLK debating with President Johnson (Tom Wilkinson), to the Governor of Alabama (Tim Roth) having state troopers beat the protestors to death on national television. It's a film full of very powerful ideas and the people who came together for their rights. It's very well done, but one complaint was it does get a bit sluggish in the middle. I found it very interesting MLK was portrayed as here. He's much more human. You always read about him, but like any other person he's just another man with his own faults. Overall, a fantastic film that I highly recommend giving a look!

Selma is deeply affecting to the point of being unsettling. Like 12 Years a Slave, the violence is visceral and whoever did the sound effects made sure we feel every bone breaking, skull fracturing blow from those batons. The movie is well acted, has particularly effective scenes involving multiple extras marching, etc.,and is both educational and artful in satisfying ways. I suspect it possible that some moviegoers may feel this is one drama too many that deals with Black history, the history of racism, and the fight for equal rights in this country given relatively recent predecessors "12 Years a Slave", "Fruitvale Station", and "The Butler" but I would discourage such cinematic fatigue and have to say if you saw those movies, as I did, go to this one as well: it's excellent. My one reservation is minor and purely a matter of personal opinion: when I see Oprah Winfrey in a movie I see...well, Oprah Winfrey, not as much her character. She is a good enough actress, but an overexposed presence across media in general. It's a bit like seeing Sean Penn in two too many political message movies. Any number of African-American actresses could've played her role in this movie; Octavia Spencer comes to mind' perhaps even Jill Scott or Gladys Knight. I don't blame Oprah for wanting to be in a movie she is sinking her heart, soul, and substantial money or power into, as this is her vision and sense of mission, but...you've done it and done it well. As Correta King says to her distraught husband when visiting him in jail: "Rest." Or at least try something totally out of character for yourself if you can't rest. That being said, I also saw Boyhood, this movie's major competition for a Best Picture Oscar. This is, to me, the more powerful film even if it did not take 12 years to shoot. If you plan to see it don't walk out too early at the end: the song "Glory" by John Legend and Common at the end is a knockout.

I liked Selma about as much as I thought I would. I didn't really care about the historical inaccuracies. The detail in the presentation, and the conveyance of the reality of being in Selma when those decisions were being made is what makes this film watchable and powerful. Starting out with MLK's Nobel Prize ceremony sets the credentials for what comes next. Strong performances and some archival footage in the credits bring the movie home.
Great film making of an important storyOyellowo portrail of MLK is incredibleThis is a must see

A gripping and immensely powerful film, Selma is nuanced, complex, intelligent and supremely emotional historical piece, led by an incredible performance from David Oyelowo and superbly directed by Ava Duvernay (who had better get a bloody Best Director nod from the Oscars, or so help me...). This is it, right here, the best film of 2014. No question.
I thought this movie was alright, but lacked what was needed to incite emotional response for a topic that should otherwise be very emotional.

This well made film focuses on one Kings most important tasks in his journey to equality. The films only negatives is its pace and tone. Being a average 2 hour film. It feels more like 3 and a half hours. But it is most certainly a must watch for all ages every where.

Solid, lovingly made docu-drama about MLK and the march from Selma to Montgomery boasts a plethora of powerful moments and a fantastic performance by David Oyelowo. While his speechifying moments don't completely soar (he matches Dr. King's cadence but somehow lacks the gravitas - a difficult feat, to be sure), he is at his best in the backstage scenes, where we get a glimpse into the weight of the movement on the man. He brings a remarkable humanity to this being of now-Superman-status, communicating the doubts and insecurities of a man forced into figurehead status. These intimate sequences are the highlights of the film, combined with a harrowing depiction of the first march across the bridge. The ensemble nature is quite nice, as well (although Tom Wilkinson and Tim Roth are too often cartoonish), but the film can't quite ever truly transcend the trappings of the genre. Still and all, what "Selma" is really about is political consciousness-raising, and at this it is very effective, reminding us of how far we've come in 50 years, and how very, very far we have to go.

Massively overrated, but the kind of movie you feel like a racist if you don't like. Starts with a halt at the Nobel awards, recovers intermittently. Excellent performances all around. Distracting little mistakes like modern buildings and modern blacked-out billboards. Good enough but definitely not great.

Selma is terrifically acted and excellently directed. And although it may focus on something that happened decades ago, it still proves that one dream changed the world, and focuses on how Martin Luther King's ideas changed America.
david oyelowo shines in a mesmerizingy captive spell of a terrific script and direction!!!
A beautiful job, I had goosebumps multiple times. His truth is marching on!

Underlined by a sober and extremely effective performance from David Oyelowo and breathtaking cinematography by Bradford Young, DuVernay's triumphant work speaks to the extent, relevance and timelessness of Martin Luther King's issues.Humane, intelligently broad and seeking the proclamation of truth to the benefit of all, Selma is exactly what it should be: a biopic done right.

Not an entertainer but an eye opener!Movie's not only the source of entertainment but also knowledge and education and have the power to bring about the change in the world. Movies like Selma tells the history when books and people can't tell enough. I dint know about the issue of voting rights of colored people in USA then but at least now I know what happened in the past. The brutal segregation and the reality behind the Emancipation Proclamation and about the Martin Luther King jr..  This movie is a chronicle of Martin Luther King's campaign to secure equal voting rights via an epic march from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama in 1965. David Oyelowo's given amazing performance as Martin Luther King and cameo from Oprah Winfrey.What I liked about the movie was the speeches made by King in inspiring people for the march. If you are looking for an entertainer the movie's not for you but If u have interest in history, politics and world this movie is certainly a good option........
Fantastic movie!!! 50 years later, we still grapple with how we treat one another.
This is a solid film that rides on the fiery passion of star David Oyelowo.

"Selma" is the best biopic I've seen in a long, long time but it is so much more. Considering the volatility and brutality portrayed, there's a surprisingly and fittingly (considering Dr. King's allegiance to non-violent resistance) quiet strength in its direction and performances that drives this movie off the screen and into your heart and conscience, simultaneously touching you with a sense of the injustices and sacrifices of our country's past while reminding you of those still present, in the present, that require sacrifices today and will tomorrow.It asks us to remember who we were, to contemplate who we are and challenges us to raise up who we could be.See this movie. Because more of us need to remember who we were, need to contemplate who we are and need to rise up to who we could be.
Selma is nothing short of a masterpiece.
With top notch performances, an exceedingly strong and hard-hitting screenplay, and fueled by emotions and dramatic power, Selma is as great as it needs to be.

Ava DuVernay's Selma is a great movie. It's driven by a stellar performance by David Oyelowo. It's beautifully filmed, and inspiring. It is definitely the kind of movie that'll get stuck in my head for a long long time. A must see.

The story of MLK in Alabama in 1965 fighting for YOUR right to vote is basically UNBEATABLE, if it has the proper screenplay, actors and director. This film lived up to all my expectations which were very high. To call it moving, or stunning or a revelation is the understatement of the year, and virtually ALL films critics agree it MUST be seen. Even if you know the story very well, it NEEDS to be seen. As i was walking out of the theatre, i heard a woman in her 70's (it seemed) talking to her companion. She said she did the 50 mile march from Selma to Birmingham which ends the film. She was not using a cane or a walker. And that brought it all home. This was not 5 centuries ago. This was less than 50 years ago. That was the America of that time, like Apartheid in South Africa at its very worst.

Current events involving police officers and their unarmed murder victims has everything and nothing to do with the firecracker that is Selma, Ava DuVernay's provocative, potent look at Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s landmark 1965 voting-rights march from Selma, Alabama to the state capitol of Montgomery. Sadly, racial injustice is as timely as ever. Righteous fury is in the air and it's that drive to be recognized as human that's all over Selma.All the better for audiences. DuVernay, working from an amazing script from Paul Webb, makes dusty history come thrillingly alive. She finds its pulse and beating heart. Dr. King, played brilliantly by Brit actor David Oyelowo, is faced with a most strenuous situation: black citizens in the South are being intimidated, beaten and discouraged from exercising their rights to vote. Alabama Gov. George Wallace (Tim Roth) is a-ok with Jim Crow. In the White House, President Lyndon Johnson (Tom Wilkinson) would rather deal with Communists, or anything else. King had to act. He believed a non-violent march in Selma, teeming with bigotry, would generate enough of a media firestorm that the president would be forced to act himself.King was right on target, but at a price. Within the burgeoning civil rights movement King faced resentment from the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee. King expected fierce opposition from proponents of violent action, but a meeting with Malcolm X (Nigel Thatch, wonderful) and King's wife Coretta (a magnificent Carmen Ejogo), a surprising strategy comes about. The political stakes are raised, and DuVernay is unflinching at showing how all hands get dirty.DuVernay's film is not about hero worship, no one is gifted with a halo, not even Dr. King. Selma is no biopic, it's a salute to community action, movement building and aims to view King through the lens of one crucial event, offering a rousing, unwavering, extraordinary portrait of a born preacher who was not without his own sins. Oyelowo's stirring, incredible performance deserves the highest of praise and superlatives. His delivery of King's speeches, particularly 'How Long, Not Long' rings true with emotion and grit. But it's in the quieter moments that he really comes alive, in moments of humor, heartache and staggering self-doubt. It's a portrait of a man in full. King and his wife discuss his infidelities with gut-wrenching honesty. Ejogo is a revelation, award-caliber in every sense.It was on March 7, known as Bloody Sunday, that black and white marchers are forced to turn back on the Edmund Pettus Bridge in the face of police. Later, a judge forces a truce and the march proceeds as planned. DuVernay and cinematographer extraordinaire Bradford Young, shooting on location in Alabama, create visual poetry as we watch history forged in real flesh and blood.Talk must be had of the two women behind Selma, the film. Oprah Winfrey, a producer on the film, is outstanding as Annie Lee Cooper, a nurse who punched a white sheriff for denying her the right to vote. Lorraine Toussaint is all kinds of excellent as Amelia Boynton, brutalized by police during the march, as is Tessa Thompson as Diane Nash, one of the movement's many unsung heroes.But the woman of the hour is undoubtedly DuVernay, a former publicist for the likes of Steven Spielberg and Clint Eastwood. Her second film, 2012's Middle of Nowhere made her the very first black woman to win the Sundance award for directing. In Selma, her talent is in full force. The task of a film to chronicle the events leading up to the passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act is immeasurable and daunting for just one film. The story is an inspiration and a tragedy considering the John Roberts Supreme Court gutted the Voting Rights Act in 2013 and racial injustice continues to plague people of color in America. The struggle goes on.

One the most life changers, gamer changer movies, I never cried so much in my life truly worth seeing how making a difference and standing up and being non-violent can bring people to make huge changes on equality for all.. My hero Martin Luther love the cast in this movie top notch acting and story had to see...

I can't really find any flaws with this film. It depicts a specific period of action, thereby focusing on the politics and humanity of the civil rights movement and sidestepping the melodrama of King's assassination. King himself is depicted as flawed and unsure of the best course of action. The movie keeps the focus on the many individuals it took to create change. There is also a scene that overtly references current events of police murdering suspects unprovoked as in Eric Garner. This movie is about today, while at the same time reminding us that yesterday, regular people took action to stop evil.

Although I found the film to be a bit slow in parts, the strong acting kept my interest. The film also does a great job of making MLK a real person who even has flaws--something I frankly haven't seen in a film before.
A powerful and visually stunning film that is so relevant in today's world.

The most recent events of police brutally and violence against minority shake the emotions of communities around the country and perhaps the world. Seems that this a vicious circle that still present without any evident solution. Ava DuVernay explore this problem in the film Selma. The historical drama Selma recount the events in 1965 of the voting rights marches led by James Hosea Williams and Martin Luther King Jr. The film's approach is raw in some moments highlighting perfectly the levels of hate and violence that people and authorities of the south have against African Americans, but also how people were able to overcome race discrimination marching as one. Selma is not a biopic about MLK is about everyone who always wanted to be treated as an equal and the struggle civil right movement leaders, finding answers and searching for understanding. Ava DuVernay do a formidable work as a director, capturing a MLK vulnerable, thoughtful and spiritual. Selma is filled with excellent visual nuances, supported by the beautiful cinematography from Bradford Young and editing by Spencer Averick. Music selection for the film is spot on and it capture the emotions of the scenes in SELMA.Lastly David Oyelowo is outstanding as a MLK he gets deep into the character, specially when he is doing the most memorable speeches from Dr King.SELMA makes you understand that nothing have change and the work to develop better understanding about race and equality is not even half away.

its a wonderful study of Luther particularly his political mind, beautifully written and superb acting. Its a powerful wake up for America, sit down and think about what we have been through and a reminder that we need to move forward not backwards as recent events showed

This is a movie that my generation needs to see. Most of us do not know our history because we are fed non-sense on a daily basis. But this, this movie gives us a little insight on who we are and how our country views us. The producers do an excellent job portraying both sides Black andWhite

There were parts of the movie that were emotionally gripping and the story needs to be told BUT there was at least a half hour that dragged on and on , making the audience restless. At times it was like watching paint dry....and for that reason it is very difficult to recommend seeing the movie.
The films strengths are the performances.

Inspiring but not hagiography. Details the process and the mechanics of the march and movement more than just a simple bio-pic. Of course one can't watch it and not think of current events, but the movie easily stands on its own merits. A truly worthy Oscar contender.

One extremely profound and historic moment (of many) during the film "Selma" occurs when viewers witness President Lyndon B. Johnson finally acquiesce to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. over his desire to conduct a protest march in Alabama. The dramatic White House scene, in which President Johnson places a call to Alabama Governor George Wallace at this insistence of Dr. King, is magnified tenfold when viewers can't help but notice a portrait of George Washington staring down at LBJ from an Oval Office wall. The symbolic message to the audience is clear. After nearly 200 years as a country--built in large part upon the backs and suffering of African-Americans--the United States was finally turning a new pageon that grim chapter of our nation's history."Selma" is a powerful, must-see film on a multitude of levels. The movie seamlessly educates, inspires and shocks audiences with knowledge, faith and unfiltered images. It unapologetically documents the importance church played in American society at one of our nation's most trying times. The film denotes the vital importance religion played in spawning renewed support from all regions the country, particularly white church goers and religious leaders. No religious spirit and kind heart was touched more so by the outpouring of followers than Martin Luther King, Jr.Director Ava DuVernay's brightest achievement in "Selma" is the palpable intensity felt, heard and seen by moviegoers as the film marches along. "Selma" justifiably depicts the deadly and graphic violence which took place against blacks in the 1960s. The multiple illustrations of inhuman treatment are necessary in this movie to fully understand the ruthlessness of so many...for so long. In contrast, and perhaps more importantly, we can see and appreciate Martin Luther King's remarkable kindness towards humanity and strong conviction that peaceful protests should remain non-violent despite sustained cruelty by others.The film's most endearing quality is the growth found in the main character over its 2-hour span. We find Dr. Martin Luther King's fortitude comes primarily from three sources-faith in his religion, support from the people, and resolve from his wife Coretta Scott King. As King gains strength from each of these pillars in his life, he's able to handle confrontations and setbacks dealt from Washington DC, Alabama whites, and even some black militants-all attempting to derail his organization's movement. It's impressive in "Selma" to see Dr. King gain influence and power from his church podium, leading a march across an Alabama bridge, or challenge a U.S. president and its citizens into action. Aside from the obvious bond to his faith, this movie sheds light on the momentous part Coretta Scott King played in her husband's life and his Civil Rights successes."Selma" is more than just a film about eliminating barriers to black voters. It's a movement about one man's place in our history--going from spiritual leader to national preacher. With steadfast determination and non-violent tactics, Dr. King used the church to gain momentum for his march between the cities of Selma and Montgomery, Alabama. In comparison to the harsh treatment from the white establishment, Martin Luther King Jr. and his non-violent ways convinced many religious organizations and whites to ultimately join his cause. The most influential of those who came around to accept Dr. King's hastened timeline, and later signed the Voter Rights Act of 1965, was the President of the United States at the time, Lyndon B. Johnson. After almost 200 years, the voices and votes of those who'd suffered the most over that period were now going to be heard and counted--finally. That's the grateful tribute of "Selma" to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and his peaceful, non-violent means to achieve a justified end...and the real reason to see this exceptional, historic story.Grade: A

That was one of the most powerful movies of the year. No matter what race or gender you are, you need to pay to see this movie and have a powerful discussion about it afterwards. It was improve your mind...and your life!
Such a powerful movie about a very important part of history.
That rare biopic that doesn't play to expectations, and ends up being vivid, surreal, and affecting.
Beautiful film. I want to see it again.

Probably the most overrated movie of 2014 in my opinion. The film can definitely be powerful at times and David Oyelowo is great as King but this movie just shows us what we already know and in an extremely dry fashion.

An incredibly obvious Oscar contender if there ever was one, "Selma" is filled to the brim with the finest of everything that a movie of this kind has to offer: Superb acting, fantastic dialogue, absolutely immaculate cinematography, and also does a fantastic job at stating one thing: Society is messed up. The fact than anyone thought that performing Mistral shows where people in Blackface is the main attraction, and the merciless, careless beating and wounding, and even barbaric killing of black people was in even considered an OK thing to do, let along legal in the United States! What Martin Luther King, Jr. did was absolutely extraordinary, and should never be left to die out.As I've stated, an absolutely fantastic, immaculate picture that does every movie of this nature is supposed to do. I, as I would with "The Imitation Game", would absolutely see this again. A indisputable must-see.

I am the first to admit my overall knowledge of the civil rights movement is very limited. I probably should catch up on my contemporary American history as I know it's not only important but we seem to be regressing to problems that were solved over 50 years ago. Selma is a well acted, well written and overall strong movie. It's a bit slow at times and there are too many meandering subplots. At times it's a bit hard to follow and the immensity of characters is imposing. Half the time I was asking myself who was important and who was just a role character. This is the kind of movie critics love and much like Lincoln, I would not be surprised if it gets plenty of awards. The acting is really good and the brutality it portrays is mind boggling. It is embarrassing to think that many of these events happened a few years before my birth.While Selma is a very good movie it's not great. I think the pace is slow and there could be a bit more focus. However, this is a film that should be watched and appreciated, in particular given the current political climate.

I can give this movie nothing less than 5/5 stars for being excellent! Oprah finally did it in making a good movie! I loved it. I was not alive during this era and I had always heard of the march from Selma Alabama to Montgomery as nothing more than a mere blurb in the history books. I had no idea how much went into this march or the personal struggles that Dr. King went through when deciding to lead it. Also liked how they were able to do this movie without being too sexual or gory which seems to be a common theme in many films today. I have no doubt that one day this will be a standard film shown in American history classes throughout our nation

Now I can see why everyone hates Alabama this much. I mean gawd damn these southern white people are some vicious assholes. So we are hardly two weeks into 2015 and already I found myself a film that is worthy of a Top 10 spot for this year with something that literally took me by surprise. Normally January is the time of month where Hollywood throws out a series of bad movies that no one either cares about or dislikes because they are, more or less, like filler as we wait to see what the Summer blockbuster films have in store. However in this rare case, everyone around the internet has been praising this film about as loudly as the King himself when he would give his speech or sermon. So I walked in with an open mind about it and came out making me hate racist white Southerners even more than I normally do. Thanks movie! So any who, this film is based on the 1965 Selma to Montgomery voting rights marches led by James Bevel, Hosea Williams, and Martin Luther King, Jr. of SCLC and John Lewis of SNCC. Don't know what those acronyms mean? Well Google it, because I'm sure you will find the answers there. So this civil march was a defining moment in US history as this allowed the desire of black American citizens to exercise their constitutional right to vote, in defiance of segregationist repression. In the heart of Alabama back in this point in 1965, a lot of African-Americans were unable to vote because a majority of its people who ran this state were racist white people. So with the help of Martin Luther King Jr., and many others, led a 54 mile march from Selma to Montgomery in order to make their point across the entire nation that every race had a right, not only to vote, but also not be harassed no matter where they go or where they live. I think that's about it. Anyway, let's march on to what I thought about this film.If you are watching this for the first time, let me tell you that the first five minutes of this movie WILL take you by surprise. What I like about this movie is that this takes place on a certain event in Martian Luther King Jr's life, and not depicting his entire life like from beginning to end like in some films like Lee Daniels: The Butler. Not that it is a bad thing, but those kind of movies tend to drag out from time to time. However not this movie, because it is one powerful looking film. This movie had hard tactics which had not only protests but negotiation and strategy to go along with it. The main actor who plays Martin Luther King Jr. in here, David Oyelowo, really may not look like MLK that much but I think he does a great job portraying him without doing an impression. I was happy that he did not go down that route because you really don't want your legendary civil rights leader sounding like an impression like other comedians have done in the past. You felt the emotion behind his performance along with many other actors that were in here. Tom Wilkinson did a fantastic job as Lyndon B. Johnson as well even though this actor is British, however he does put together some great dialogue in a lot of scenes. As for the worst parts in this movie, well...define "Worst" because my definition for worse in this film would be for anyone that is not white if they watched this in theaters. The brutality in this movie captured all of it a little too well. You see both whites and blacks from men, women, and children being beaten and murdered with no justice behind it and the president is treating this like it's just another day in the South. When I say that the brutality is filmed too well, I mean that you really do feel emotional when you watch those horrific scenes. I hunkered down into my seat hoping no black people would get angry and start cursing me out. Overall, this movie is one for the ages with every single actor being absolutely superb, capturing both the emotions & passion from these real life people, and showing the pure brutality that went on back in those days made you really feel for them and their hardships that they went through to get what they want in the end. Easily a...four and a half star movie if I ever saw one.

Recently, I've overheard quite a few people comment on how they believe Hollywood is over "the black thing." I was never quite sure what that meant, but I assumed it means people think Hollywood has seen enough movies revolving around race-related stories. Of course, "12 Years a Slave" won Best Picture last year, and maybe that's what the people I overheard were referring to. But let me ask this: How many films are there about Martin Luther King, Jr.? Can you think of one? Now, think about Abraham Lincoln. How many times has he been portrayed in film? Two years ago we had two movies about Alfred Hitchcock. And how many times has Richard Nixon been portrayed on film? And what about... you know what, you get the idea. If there's one thing to consider before watching "Selma," it's this: "Selma," directed by Ava DuVernay, is not a movie about Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. It's about what happened in Selma, Alabama in 1964 (with Dr. King at its epicenter). The story of "Selma" is bigger than Dr. King, and I think he'd be proud of that. David Oyelowo portrays Dr. King as being tired - tired of fighting the same fight, and continuing to lose that fight despite gaining tiny bits of ground. Oyelowo plays Dr. King as human - with flaws, hopes, dreams, and determination. This is one of the greatest performances this year. And I think "the black thing" will be over when we finally judge movies and performances not by the color of their actors, but by the performances themselves. I could continue writing and praising the film and its script, direction, performances, production, but I think the film speaks loudly - and proudly - for itself. This is a movie every American should see. So, instead of continuing to write here, I'd rather challenge you to complete this sentence: I have a dream...
Good movie but Malcolm X was way better and it win an Oscar.

Powerful, important, and above all else, a very good movie that doesn't get super preachy.Much like how Lincoln focused mainly on Lincoln's attempt to pass the 13th Amendment, this film focuses primarily on the period before and after events in Selma in the 1960s, where beatings of African-Americans were shown on the news to almost all of America. Also like Lincoln, the film spends a lot of time on the wheeling and dealing behind the scenes. It's not exactly an unstoppable force meeting an immovable object, but that's not too far off the mark.David Oyelowo plays Martin Luther King Jr, and does so with all the fire and brimstone one would expect, but also a little political savvy as well. He gives a very good performance, is never portrayed as Godlike or perfect, in fact, he's given a few rather human moments as well. The second best performance belongs to Tom Wilkinson, portraying Lyndon Johnson. Wilkinson gets Johnson perfectly right down to his crass vocabulary and "zero fucks given" attitude (LBJ was known for being intimidating during meetings and even holding some while he was sitting on the toilet), but also portrays him as a man with his hands tied in a very good scene where he says while King has one problem, he has 100.There are many other actors who get there chance to shine. This is a very ensemble like movie, but it's also very well-written, giving each side a good look at what is going on from their perspective. Does it show injustice and talk about the struggle African-Americans face? Absolutely, but it never gets too preachy or too in your face. It's worth checking out for a good look at a very chaotic period in American history.
Much of Selma's power rests on the shoulders of its lead, David Oyelowo, who vividly embodies the voice, character, and mannerisms of one of history's most articulate heroes.
Great cinematography and a great performance by Oyelowo.
Powerful, Raw, and Unflinching! Sadly not much has changed... so many lives lost to hate... but we shall overcome!
It is always amazed me how people can't seem to find the time to vote when, so many have fought for the right.

Okay, this one's worthy of a few more sentences than normal. Yes, Oyelowo's performance as King shines through, even if it occasionally descends into the realm of caricature, but the screenplay undoes him at every term, unable to decide whether or not to focus on King the man or the events at Selma proper. It settles instead for a bizarre mixture of overwrought family drama, gratuitous violence, and ham-fisted political commentary, and none of it works at all. Though it has a handful of profoundly affecting moments, the vast majority of the film feels like it was written with a pen that somebody accidentally dropped into a sugar bowl. Characters constantly pander to the audience, speaking as if they know the future and generally behaving like the pawns of a writer more interested in scoring political points than writing believable dialogue. All-in-all, the film is the very definition of Oscar-bait: a safe, broadly-drawn drama that reveals exactly as much as a reading of the SCLC's Wikipedia page would, provided it was set to a stirring score.

Unlike his contemporary -- and occasional opposition -- Malcolm X, whose legacy as a controversial Brother of Islam and Civil Rights leader provided fertile ground for Spike Lee to create his monumental and epic 1992 biopic, one of the genre's very best offerings, Martin Luther King Jr. hasn't seen the silver screen nearly as much, if not at all (save the 2001 HBO telefilm BOYCOTT with Jeffrey Wright). Since King's assassination in 1968, he's become more of a monument than a man -- his name serving as a holiday and providing the perfect introduction into the topic of civil rights for learning kids and adults. Making a film about this tremendous man that holds true to his legacy, but still encapsulates his human frailties, is a dangerous territory for any filmmaker, one that hardly guarantees any success at all. Credit should be given then to Ava DuVernay, who rightfully accepted this dubious challenge and has successfully captured a version of King's life and put it onto film. Honestly, SELMA is hardly the definitive film of King, focusing rather on several weeks in the life of the man, as Spielberg's LINCOLN did, rather than portraying his entire life, like Lee's MALCOLM X. It's also not the precise cure to the now common biopic either. It is, however, a refreshing and intense collection of gripping performances, inspiring power, and beautiful cinematography. DuVernay condenses some years of importance into one-sided expository dialogue exchanges that are used to either skim over some historical happenings or provide other points-of-view, but it sort of works here. DuVernay seems to understand King best when he's at the podium, and she uses these scenes to their full advantage, but there are smaller scenes that calculate the man as well. These sequences -- going back and forth between the public and private Martin Luther King -- are made even more resonant by David Oyelowo's incredible performance, a performance that I might just call the best of the year, maybe tying with Michael Keaton's work in BIRDMAN and Jake Gyllenhaal's in NIGHTCRAWLER. So, although Selma isn't necessarily the complete portrait of King that others were clamoring for, it still prospers in that this is a film about a man whose guidance and teachings are needed to be heard more than ever. In the awkward, tragic aftershock of the situation in Ferguson, racial tension is at a high that hasn't been seen since perhaps just the era this film focuses on. This movie is important. It's peaceful, yet inspiring and powerful voice can be heard through its echoing cries into the microphone of the great MLK and can be seen through its beautiful color palette, steeped in the warm, milky tones of the 60s. This is a gorgeous looking film that begs and deserves to be seen by everyone who cares to listen to its peaceful protest.

A powerful tale that is brought to life by moving performances, assured direction, and an uncommonly honest agenda.

David Oyelowo paints this man, Martin Luther King with one of the flat out best leading performances of the year, bring Martin Luther King back from the dead it almost seems for this movie. Impeccably written, masterfully directed, and wonderfully acted (especially by David Oyelowo), Selma serves as a careful reminder of an important time in American history, and how its message could not be more timely.

David Oyelowo gives a phenomenal performance as Dr. King and DuVernay does a incredibly accurate and powerful job directing this cinematic masterpiece that should be seen by everyone.

Selma is a very good film about an historical episode that had huge consequences for the change and evolutions of laws in the 60's for African American people. wonderfully shot and acted, this film is a case study of the fight led by Dr. King and his followers to gain the right to vote like any other citizens. Powerful & gritty film depicting the important Selma march, thanks to outstanding performances & Ava DuVernay's down to earth direction. David Oyelowo is brilliant depicting MLK, not physically looking like him but capturing his mannerisms & passion with precision, especially in his numerous speeches throughout the film. He gets able support around him, particularly Tom Wilkinson as LBJ & Tim Roth as George Wallace, who manages to bring some humanity to the former racist Democratic governor. Behind the camera, DuVernay gives a nice behind the scenes view of how the events formed, displaying King not only as a passionate civil rights activist but a cagey politician who selected Selma for a specific reason. The film also doesn't gloss over King, depicting him as a human being with real flaws, including a particular infamous one. Overall, one of the finest dramas of 2014 and sure to be seen throughout the award season.
An absolutely remarkable film. Great acting, directing and cinematography. The story is riveting. The naysayers need to make a documentary. This is a movie and an excellent one.

It is one of the most powerful moves that I have ever seen. Even though they needed to change MLK speeches and LBJ's character arc, they did a magnificent job in writing a story about MLK figuring out a way to get Washington and LBJ to see that a national law needs to get passed so that Blacks can vote. Lastly, the acting was superb especially for David Oyelowo and the supporting cast was great too. EVERYONE NEEDS TO SEE THIS FILM!!

Poignant , revealing and inspiring. DuVernays biopic tells a great story of triumph and revelation into a period of history that we must never forget. A genuine performance by Oyelowo surrounded by a timid yet powerful cast allow this movie from the dramatic to the realistic.

This movie isn't like every "black" history movie. To me it has soul and heart in it. Movies like 42 I didn't enjoy because it was too sappy and overdue on mean people on the white side. I understand that this was our world and a lot of white people were bad. Though like Selma, it shows us that there are people in the world that are good. That whites and blacks can come together and make peace. This also had great casting, David is fantastic as MLK and really shows how powerful of a man he was. Also how humane the great man was. This also doesn't force too much on the violence itself or has parts of boredom. It treats us with accurate and fair accounts of Selma Alabama and the troubles of what they went through. I would have liked a broader stroke of what MLK did and not just of one city. The ending seemed to be rushed. Though I'm glad they didn't just end it with MLK speech. That would have been cliche and boring. To me it paints a portrait of what real cinema should focus on. Not this over analyzed ideas of "black vs. whites" or scenes after scenes of brutality. Also of over abundance emotion that sucks the life out of the scene. Emotion is good and this movie does its share of its. Though it sticks to action and a certain code. Telling the story as well and as straight forward as possible. No fluff, no boundaries, and nothing that would distract from the story itself. It shows us that there are movies out there that can produce great cinema. Overall the story is great and the performances were the best part. 9.3Also, I love stylistic movies and this was a perfect example of a great stylistic movie.

First must see movie of the year for me, Selma lived up to the reviews. An excellent film sprinkled with cameos from many fine actors. The lead, Oyelowo, is superb. The story from 50 years ago resonates on several levels today. Well made, well paced and directed, I highly recommend this film.

Ava DuVernay does an excellent job at bringing out real emotion through imagery. There was a point in the film where I literally felt such horror at the way mankind treats one another, and this was accomplished even without showing any excessive amounts of violence. That said, the message was a little heavy handed, a trait I see from many movies directed by women. In the end, this is a must see not only for historical appreciation, but also for its gripping emotional impact.

a rare movie that shows the real history behind one of the most influential figures in AmericaDavid Oyelowo expertly plays the late Martin Luther King, Jr. leading the long journey to secure the VRA in the 1960severyone else fills their roles with care; Tom Wilkinson as the stubborn, reluctant Lyndon B. Johnson, Tim Roth as the close-minded Governor George Wallace, and even Oprah Winfrey as a woman wanting to registerit really shows how far we as the people have come giving African Americans their constitutional right to vote, and the movie is extremely socially relevant in our present day society seeing rioting, civil unrest, and tuning into the news hearing about public violence affecting usthe racism, prejudice, hatred and fear still exist in many forms and we still have a long way to go to be rid of it forevernot everything is black and white as King made it out to be, he truly opened the door for equality to flourish despite so many limitationsthe march from Montgomery to Selma, Alabama shows true courage and realistic accuracy of how hard King's task wasthe movie is a fantastic representation of King, his family, his friends, and the overall change that took place and became so monumental one of 2015's finest films that shouldn't be missed

Very well done film. Oyelowo does an insanely good job as MLK. Very well written and all the major players in the story are involved. See this. If you care at all about the future of our country, see this.

A Striking and heart stirring film, it avoids the trappings of traditional biopics, little bias, doesn't portray him as a saint or a weakling but as a human. The narrative is flowing but sometimes ill-paced. Overall, this film; at it's heart, is filled with emotion and is a no frills account of MLK and his crusade in Selma. This will be a film for the ages.

Powerful, relevant, and incredibly important, SELMA is a knockout film focusing on one specific front in Martin Luther King Jr.'s long, civil rights movement. Oyelowo gives a career defining performance as MLK, but is surrounded by one of the years most eclectic and perfect supporting casts. As far as biopics go, its still fairly color-by-numbers, but the pacing and cinematography stand out and the film's historically powerful events overshadow any minor flaws. A film for all Americans.

Terrific movie. Very inspiring, well made, important subject.
This is one of those movies that's so good that words can barely describe it.

I have not saw this movie...I will see it at some point. It is probably a good move. I am not a fan of the same stories being retold over and over again no matter how great the stories are. David Oyelowo Played Excellently as King The Junior But the movie talks about single thing what he did for African American
Oyelowo is fantastic and even if other aspects of the film drift into standard dramatic biopic territory, the movie itself never stumbles.

DuVernay has made a beautiful, stirring, emotionally potent film. Oyelowo, good in last year's "The Butler," is phenomenal here, giving a fully human portrayal of an historical giant. Ejogo, as his wife, is sublime and every bit his equal. The film does have "an LBJ problem" - painting him in too-broad strokes in comparison to the subtle depth afforded to smaller characters - but it is not the fatal flaw it could have been in a less compelling and affecting film. If it's not nominated for multiple Oscars that will only be because enough voters didn't see it, because this film cannot be seen and subsequently not admired.

While it was a well intentioned effort at examining the dynamics and strong personalities behind the march to Selma and the subsequent signing of the Voting Rights Act, there were several intriguing threads that were glanced at, then left unexamined. Malcolm X's influence on Dr. King's movement was mentioned then left out of the conversation thereafter, as well as the first tentative displays of respect between the marchers and the State police when Dr. King refused to continue his second march after the troopers withdrew were ignored in the film. Understandably, when issues are so vast, the filmmakers have to decide what's relevant to the picture they are making and what is extraneous, but those two factors I felt left me feeling I was not given the whole story and I left the cinema unsatisfied.

This film chronicles the struggles and the preseverance of Americans who believe in the dream of all are created equal. It also reminds you of how far this country has come. I was an honor to see this movie with my grandmom (76). Her comment , "this country is diversed and what a beautiful sight." This is an awesome film!!

The actors playing King and Johnson are perversely miscast, bsrly no resemblance either visually or vocally to their real life counterparts. The pace is glacial, the drama inert. It takes a lot of effort to turn one of the most dramatic moments in history into something this dull. Still, the story itself is so important, it still manages to hold the attention.

+In the film "Selma" David Oylowo jumps ahead of the pack of actors definitely in the race for a Best Actor Oscar nomination. Though this is not a biography of Martin Luther King, the role he plays, it does show the man with all his strengths and many of his weaknesses. King did not plan or organize the marches the film centers on but took the lead when they happened.The film centers around 3 marches that took place in Alabama to protest the discriminatory practices that took place to stop black people from going to the polls though they did have the right to vote. The 54 mile march was to go from the town of Selma to Montgomery, the capitol of Alabama, to confront the Governor, George Wallace, played by Tim Roth.The facts of the marches were recorded and though they are the center of the film the screenplay by Paul Webb concentrates of real human beings, famous or not, who were involved. Those who lived through those violent and history making days will have their memories refreshed of what did happen and along the way learn things that took place unbeknown to them.There are some concerns about how the film portrays President Lyndon B. Johnson, played by Tom Wilkinson, showing him in private talks with Dr. King and between the President and Governor Wallace. This is a Hollywood story and there are no witnesses to the discussions that took place so depending on your thoughts you may feel one way or the other but by turning the light on individuals this becomes many personal stories.The 3 protest marches took place in March, 1967. The first ended when the State troopers and county policeman attacked the 500 marchers with billy clubs and using tear gas. A picture of Amelia Boynton, played by Lorraine Toussaint, beaten unconscious and laying on the ground, was shown all over the world with other pictures of violence, which had also been televised, with that day becoming known as 'bloody Sunday'. You may not know or remember what took place at the other 2 marches but you will see that in the film.By its nature "Selma" is a violent film, though none of the scenes are gratuitous, and shows just enough to make a point without turning the audience off. One of the minor faults of the film is that except for the violence that took place there is very little heft in the drama that took place away from the marches which may have been what the director wanted.The acting, minor and major roles, is of the first order whether it be Carmen Ejogo as Coretta Scott King, Andre Holland as Andrew Young, Dylan Baker as J. Edgar Hoover, Stephen Root as Al Lingo along with Trai Byers, Stephan James, Cuban Gooding, Jr., just to mention a few. Oprah Winfrey as Annie Lee Cooper blends in as one of the crowd and, like them, is her character and not star.Though this film belongs to David Oyelowo, the director Ava DuVernay owns every shot, showing what needs to be shown without overdoing it. The scenes of the dyed in the wool racism shown by Wallace, local police, white citizens of Alabama are true to life and not 'stacked' in anyone's favor. There is talk that she may become the first black female director nominated for an Oscar and it is certainly worth that recognition."Selma" can be seen as a 'history lesson' but it is more of a reminder of America's past and also can be related to America's present.

It amazes me that anyone would give this movie less than 5 stars; especiallly critics. Perhaps that in itself is suggestive that the true race relations struggle still persists. For all accounts - and on the merits of fine film making, riveting historical accounts and superb acting - this film is one of the most important and beautiful art pieces of our time. This is the first feature film ever made about the monumental and life altering events at Selma that set the course for historic legislation. While telling that story we are privileged to peek into the more human, more fallible life of Dr. King, his family and his most trusted advisors and fellow freedom fighters. Striking the balance between these realities is certainly not easy, but DuVernay is brilliant and the cast is extraordinary. Something I hope is not lost on any audience member is the question of what do we want our own legacy to be. If people missed this core tenant from the film, they were not paying close enough attention.

Incredibly moving and believable depiction of the martyr Martin Luther King Jr. David Oyelowo mesmerizes when on screen. Wonderful acting by the entire cast. They made this painful subject matter easier to watch.

The film is actually your standard history/biographical film and not the hard hitting new-take of the events that the promotions of the film would have you believe. In saying that, "Selma" is a terrific film that while is centered on Martin Luther King Jr. as a principle player, does not lose focus on the greater movement of which he lead both as a person and a symbol. David Oyelowo is simply great as King and deserves all the praises he shall recieve, and I especially liked Tom Wilkinson as President Johnson.

an inaccurate representation of Lyndon Johnson's role is this piece of history is upsetting; Lyndon Johnson's role in the civil issues of that time period was big and gutsy and he does not deserve to be maligned. We know that many viewing this film will now think about Johnson's role as negative --- the films representation of Johnson will be remembered as truth when it is not the truth. The director has done history a misservice
Movie was an outstanding portrayal of a critical time in American history

(Yes, I am soooo tired of hearing my parents, grandparents and other relatives tell me how important this is. But old folks just keep living in the past. Good film but by no means great. The director made some odd choices also; she devotes almost four minutes to a conversation between King and a father whose son was killed by cops and totally ignores any of Malcolm X's talk with a black Selma church congregation. I would have thought that the effort by America's most notorious black militant to reach out to King' pacific movement would have been worth a few words at least. Her attempt to introduce Hoover and LBJ's evil machinations seems scattershot also, at the price of diluting the passions and emotions generated by the march from Selma to Montgomery. The movie is getting a lot of praise and hype more for the subject than quality, I suspect.

I think it is unfortunate that the Producers, Directors, Writers felt it was necessary to misrepresent President Johnson and his total support for Blacks and voters rights for Blacks in this movie. All documented on taped conversations. The movie would be stronger with historical accuracy.

'Selma' is an amazing movie. The movie is not for you if you want to hide from the world and deny that there's an "issue" and that there has been an "issue" for our whole history. The movie IS for you if you want to be ignorant because . . . well, you should not be. Pure and simple. The movie is spectacularly acted and wonderfully directed. It goes places that you wouldn't expect and is about King's struggle within himself, as well as the movement and, of course, the march from Selma. It's painfully sad to see so many parallels between what happened 40 years and today . . . and I hate that what was fought for with so much blood, sweat, tears and death so many years ago has not been won. But this movie will force us to look in the mirror, as well as at our history, and perhaps film/art will bring discussions of race and a new civil rights movement back to the forefront. One can only hope. I know that I will be having my own conversations.

I appreciated the humanizing of King (and of Johnson), though I did not find it as tastefully done as in "Lincoln." I also did not feel that the movie fully capitalized on the timbre of MLK's voice.
There was a round of applause at the end of this movie! You truly see how much these people had to go through.
I loved Selma very much in the same way I loved Lincoln. They both show a tactical and human look at history and those who would shape it.
Saw this film last night! Very, very powerful!
Great American movie. Too bad a ton of Americans wont see it..

Selma is a good movie, not a great one, but because of it's subject matter it's virtues are likely to be exaggerated while its flaws greatly downplayed. First of all, it took some serious historical liberties regarding the relationship between LBJ and King. This isn't a trivial point because the tension between the two is a key source of drama in the movie. Additionally, Selma had a certain tendency to rely on King speaking to add dramatic effect, rather than the actual events, which is ironic because the speeches made weren't even King's to begin with. That said, David Oyelowo is a force and carries the film at certain points beyond its merits.
David Oyelowo, a Brit in a film full of Brits, gives the performance of a lifetime...

Provided a lot of insight into the mini events that hasn't really been told in other movies which have featured the events around Selma, AL. I thought it was a good movie. A little monotone at times which took away the interest of my 16 yr old son and 20 yr old daughter. Definitely a must see movie though and seems to almost be a lot like a documentary type of film.

Selma is a compelling film based on the events of one of the most important American citizens of all time, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., with a solid performance by David Oyelowo as Dr. King, intense and gripping story, and an uncomfortable yet overall inspirational film for anyone who wants to make a difference in the world!

'Selma' is a movie that gains it's power through intimacy, no showy biographical picture stunts like in 'Unbroken'. David Oyelowo gives maybe the best performance any actor has given playing a real life, historical figure! Yes, maybe more than Daniel Day Lewis did in 'Lincoln'. This is a commanding but also quiet, subtly powerful performance! The entire cast is amazing as is the magnificent directing by Ava DuVernay. This is directing that may become legendary. 'Selma' has beautiful one on one moments and no grandstanding whatsoever! The antithesis of a history lesson, the movie soars at just giving us multiple quiet, affecting moments of truth.

It's good. It's not great. Each strength - the cinematography, Oyelowo's performance, the extremely rare Hollywood movie that doesn't offer a white POV character, the stunningly impressive second scene - is matched by a flaw, primarily flaws of tidying up history to fit a particular world view. SELMA is valuable as entertainment and to prompt examination of history, it's damaging if it's blindly accepted as history.

I iived through this time period and I didn't really understand everything that happened until I saw Selma. Emotionally gripping and draining. If you only see one movie this year, go see THIS one. "God I hate having to wait for movies. Seems my previous Top 20 Best list needs to be updated. Emotionally powerful, Featuring one of the best casts of the year. Especially David Oyelowo, Who's performance is a fine piece of acting. To me, 2014 isn't quite over yet."
Provocative. Emotional. Real. Transcendent. Rarely can a biopic effortless retell history in the absence of agenda. Selma captures the essence of why film can still be art.

This movie is a powerful examination of a pivotal point in American history. It is both poignant and inspiring and going forward should be required viewing for anyone who has forgotten what it took to get where we are today.

Selma feels more like a civil rights film than a Martin Luther King film. It takes us on a journey with the activists of the movement, and makes us understand what it means to be a part of it all. With this portrait of the civil rights era, DuVernay is concerned with stirring our emotions during stunningly well-made scenes of brutality and giving us the feeling of being among these people. There are many vehicles through which we witness the movement and they create a whole that is detailed with the many personal and societal values that the movement embodied. Of course, the main attraction here looks to be MLK, and yet it doesn't quite feel like that is the best attraction. Oyelowo is great as King, physically and emotionally he seems to embody the man who we've heard so much about but have never seen up close. His portrayal is all about the up-close. While Oyelowo's portrayal of King is magnificent, the film doesn't put him at the center of our focus and we don't really get inside of his head. Instead there are an abundance of supporting players that give us the experience of the movement, but at the expense of what could have been a truly great character study. For sure, we get moments where King grapples with his responsibilities and flaws, moments that I appreciated, but it's muted by the feeling of the movement and the weight of characters around him.  Selma is at its most successful when it goes big and broad, speaking for MLK's movement and appealing to the emotions of those involved. Scenes like the one on the bridge are phenomenal, and some of the most riveting and emotionally stirring moments that I've seen on screen all year. While DuVernay's style didn't work for me all the time, it is during these scenes where everything was absolutely perfect, and her talent glows. The film attaches itself to the humanity and emotion of these moments through DuVernay's rushing camera and some sharp editing and cinematography. DuVernay attaches us to many different characters throughout, all of whom feel unified by the motivation of the movement, allowing the switch of perspective to not only feel appropriate, but to highlight the unity that the activists felt towards one other. We get close to just about everybody: the activists, the historical figures, the opposers, the political figures. A sense of the entirely of the era is established, but in return the film doesn't dig in deeply as I would have liked it to into one area or one character. It speaks very well for the history but less well for the individuals. The cinematography from the talented Bradford Young always looks nice and when the movie is at its best, it's fantastic, but it sometimes felt unmotivated. There are a lot of lens flares and glows that don't seem to do anything for the film itself. The colors are great though, and overall it succeeds in capturing the feel of the time. I felt the same about the editing, where in talky scenes the choices feel random and overcomplicated, but in most scenes it's very affective in juggling the abundance of characters and letting the emotions speak. Like the movie as a whole, these elements work much better, in fact extremely well, in scenes that capture a lot of action and tension, and less in intimate character moments.  For all the criticism I sound like I'm giving the movie, yes, it could have been better, but what it does well it does WELL. In movies where the general consensus is above my opinion I'm more wordy with my dislikes. Selma does a lot, and overall it speaks deeply and intelligently for the civil rights movement, and it's well worth seeing for that. In the brief moment that this film captures, it says a lot about what it means to fight for one's rights. And boy is it timely right now. You can't watch the film and not think about the marches that have been going on recently, and the movie speaks very well for those, too. Unfortunately what keeps this movie from being great for me is the lack of memorable character moments from King and others.

Main characters are well acted and fleshed out. Everyone else is a cardboard caricature. I blame this on the monochromatic and overly simplistic script that gives us the story with almost no shades of gray.
Great performances from the cast and a great historical story on Martin Luther King Jr.
Too much dialogue. Average flick. But will receive many honors because of its liberal theme.
A moving and powerful perspective on the bravery and faith of the civil rights leadership. Wish my grandfather was alive to see this perspective. Much different than the stories he was told....
Tremendous! Thinking fondly of all my "Stony..." friends! Feeling so fortunate to have taken that workshop and walked across the Edmund Pettus Bridge with my collegues..
One of the best movies I saw in a long time. Powerful!
How to win a struggle, within a discriminative law, without a single bullet, without a single bomb.

Best movie of the year. Fantastic. Nuanced, intelligent, and extremely powerful. I cried through most of it simply because of the sheer overwhelming powerful emotions that emanated from inside watching the strength and courage of the people involved in these marches. David Oyelowo is brilliant as Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr displaying his eloquence, strength and thoughtful approach to what he was working to accomplish. I was so ashamed of my country watching this. These events did not occur that long ago and they are inexcusable. And, now we see some people trying to put restrictions on voting rights again now, in our day - we are treading dangerous waters here. How far is too far. Watch Selma and consider carefully where we are headed. Okay - rant over on current events. As a film, this is just so excellent. I was in an audience with mostly African-American women who had lived during the time of these events and we all agreed that high school history teachers should have their students watch this and then discuss. There have been some issues with how President Johnson was portrayed in this because he was in favor of Civil Rights, although the movie indicates his hesitancy regarding King's movement. Johnson was, truly, in favor of Civil Rights, he was just trying to focus on poverty issues rather than voting rights, not fully understanding the necessity of how voting rights were intertwined so intimately with poverty issues. Hats off to Ava DuVernay who directed this with the perfect touch, fantastic shots, appropriate indications of the violence faced by the protestors without it being too graphic for viewers so that viewers could truly see the brutality without having to turn away from it - unlike some directors who might have used shots of gratuitous violence simply because that is how they direct. Carmen Ejogo was stunning as strong, yet understandably frightened for her family, Coretta Scott King. Oprah Winfrey portrays a woman who persists in efforts to vote, although you can clearly see the hopelessness on her face, in her posture, yet she doesn't give up. But, of course, Oprah is always wonderful. To sum up for Oscar purposes, which is what my little entertainment world revolves around, PLEASE nominations (and I'm saying wins) for Best Picture, Best Director and Best Leading Actor. That is my call at this time, though I have yet to see some of the other contenders out there, but I don't see those three choices changing. Pure excellence.
The historically inaccuracies were distracting when it came to politics, but Oyelowo was great. Some interesting interest never focused on before in film, and that will keep your interest.
Despite Oyelowo's great performance, the picture's direction feels like a jumbled effort; trying to glorify it's hero and also trying to show all his faults as well.

Its a good movie. Reminded me a lot of "Lincoln." But I think Michael Gambon did a better LBJ in "Path to War." There's a line on how much he hated dealing with those "f#@ing Kennedies" that still makes me chuckle.
A moving and important movie. It's definitely a must-see.
Too many historical inaccuracies.

Selma is the rare biopic where you get to watch what actually happens around the main character and not just find him in every second of the movie. David Oyelowo gives a career making performance that's easily one of the best performances of the year. His performance soars every time he gives a speech, just like the real Martin Luther King. Ava Duvernay succeeds at delivering the urgency and the tension that the era that the movie takes place in had with a terrific pace and a confident style, and showcased how charismatic, bold, and even flawed King was, in a very relatable manner.
of course they did...they are all liberals that went to see it
An excellent portrayal of a tough time in American history. Oyelowo does an amazing job as Dr. King.
Powerful, emotional, lived it, now saw it. Saw Dr. King give a powerful speech in Joliet before a packed Memorial Stadium after Selma.
Thanks to David Oyelowo's great performance and the film's inspirational third act, Selma manages to be a watchable biopic.
I saw Selma last night. It is an important taste of the reality of the times, with validity within the realities of today.

This film's release cannot be better timed than now. With a powerful lead performance and a narrative that is more inspiring than it is depressing, Selma avoids conventional biopic traits, reminding us that the battle of racism still exists today and that there is much more work to be done
Magnificent, inspiring, empowering, and beautifully crafted motion picture.

Selma is exactly the type of powerhouse semi-bio-pic that Hollywood should produce more frequently. It forgoes the hagiographic content of other historical films, and instead finds it's emotional edge through depicting harrowing events, and raw human emotion. Lifted by an all-star cast (and I don't use that term lightly) Selma is clearly one of the best Oscar hopefuls this season, and it couldn't have been released in theater at a better time too.
Powerful and raw. Oyelowo's performance is amazing and his speeches are flawless.DuVernay is a brilliant and wonderful director.I love everything about this movie.
